So What‚Äôs It About?
In a corporate-dominated space-faring future, planetary missions must be approved and supplied by the Company. For their own safety, exploratory teams are accompanied by Company-supplied security androids. But in a society where contracts are awarded to the lowest bidder, safety isn‚Äôt a primary concern.

On a distant planet, a team of scientists is conducting surface tests, shadowed by their Company-supplied ‚Äòdroid--a self-aware SecUnit that has hacked its own governor module and refers to itself (though never out loud) as ‚ÄúMurderbot.‚Äù Scornful of humans, Murderbot wants is to be left alone long enough to figure out who it is, but when a neighboring mission goes dark, it's up to the scientists and Murderbot to get to the truth.

What I Thought

I‚Äôve heard people sing praise to Murderbot for years now, and I‚Äôm kind of embarrassed that it took me so long to get on the bandwagon. But I read All Systems Red! Finally! And now I‚Äôm bandwaggoned!

This novella is fast-paced, inventive, and clever all throughout. Murderbot‚Äôs head is a fascinating one to be in, both because of how it sees the world and functions through technology and because of its complete awkwardness and mortification around humans. I think this is really well done given the way it has existed with and been treated by humans before. You might expect Murderbot to immediately embrace kind treatment instead of what it usually receives, but it responds with panic instead, which feels like such smart writing and characterization.

Despite its alleged apathy towards humankind, Murderbot is still really fond of its humans and does its very best to take care of them as best it knows how. I also really loved seeing how humans reacted to it. Some trusted it while others didn‚Äôt; some saw it as an equal person while others didn‚Äôt; some asked disconcerting questions about whether it hates or blames humans.

My only real complaint is that I think Wells missed an incredible opportunity by choosing not to incorporate the media Murderbot loves more. We‚Äôre always hearing about how it goes off to watch its shows, but I wish we had heard more about the actual content of those shows and what Murderbot thinks of them. There‚Äôs an incredible moment where someone in the team reveals that Murderbot has been watching human media and another person says something about one of the characters on the soap opera it‚Äôs watching being guilty of a salacious act that they were accused of. To this (completely distracted from the confrontation it‚Äôs in the middle of) Murderbot heatedly responds ‚ÄúNo, she fucking didn‚Äôt.‚Äù I LOVED this moment. It‚Äôs hilarious, of course, but it‚Äôs also just such a good moment of characterization - a show of rare, relatable emotion that demonstrates how invested Murderbot is in its media. I could see this getting overdone, of course, but I think even a few more moments like that could have added so much. That being said, this was an incredible amount of fun and I can‚Äôt wait to read more!

What was I supposed to do, kill all human because the ones in charge of constructs in the company were callous? Granted, I liked the imaginary people on the entertainment feed way more than I liked real ones, but you can‚Äôt have one without the other.

Should I be worried? I spent the last three months endlessly watching entertaining feeds and/or raging at stupid people in the news. I might be turning into a murderbot, or maybe I am simply programmed to think I am human, until my secret corporate masters will push the button to activate me. You‚Äôd better watch out, there will be mayhem once I go out of quarantine!

All System Red is the first novella in a new science-fiction project that is tightly plotted, fast-paced and funny. A first person narration from a serial killer perspective, our host is a construct of organic and electronic elements, a Security bot assigned to a geological survey team on a recently discovered exoplanet.

We all know, thanks to Isaac Asimov, that robots and artificial intelligence in general are subjected to the Laws of Robotics, the prime directive of which says that they should not harm their human masters. But an artificial intelligence is by definition a software capable of learning, and the one that calls itself Murderbot has taught itself some high level hacker code, enough to disable the governor that enforces the Law of Robotics. In its own defense, the Murderbot is annoyed when put to work for the survey team, preferring instead to watch endless re-runs of popular soap operas in space. Because, you know, anything is better than going back to work!

Joking aside, the novella does a great job at setting up the debate of how we define humanity and how we take responsibility for our own actions.
I will probably read the next three episodes in the following days, curious to see how free will can deal with deeply entrenched paranoia against armed and dangerous intelligent entities who take a critical view of our society.

‚ÄòAll Systems Red‚Äô by Martha Wells is the first of what will be called the Murderbot Diaries. The narrator is a snarky robot who speaks like a witty teenager. Xe (it does not have a sex, so using s/he pronouns are erroneous, so, I will use Xe) is a security bot or SecUnit. Xe works for a commercial company responsible for setting up transportation, habitat construction and security for other private for-profit companies or humanitarian or scientific non-profits who wish to explore other planets occupied by non-sentient life forms or simply planetary objects which have important minerals which can be monetized.

Xe calls itself Murderbot because its programming involves killing anything which threatens the people who have contracted with the Company for exploration services. However, the Company and everybody else does not know Murderbot hacked its own governor module after a previous protection assignment went wrong. Xe has been autonomous ever since.

As the novella opens, Xe is protecting a non-profit group of scientists exploring a planet full of non-sentient life. Xe thinks they seem nice, but humans do not really interest Xe beyond paying attention if they ask it. Mostly Xe watches downloads of soap operas while scanning the area for trouble periodically.

Xe‚Äôs humans are busy exploring a crater when stuff begins to happen which require Xe's services - very bad, life-threatening stuff, the kind of trouble which looks like someone or something is trying to kill all of the scientists! The scientists are scared and so is Xe! What is going on? It is possible from clues that Murderbot's owners, the Company, could be part of whatever is happening. Something issued a command to Xe, trying to take control. No one knows Xe hacked the governor module, so Xe is on its own. As far as Xe is concerned, no one is going to harm the human scientists! Xe sort of likes them. So do I, gentle reader.

I highly recommend this novella. It is a really fun adventure, well written, and very entertaining. It also is sneakily exploring situations in which people and sentient, but enslaved, robots might find themselves interacting.

Xe felt female to me, but maybe you will see Xe differently. Let me know.

It soon becomes apparent that the members of the survey team in the SecUnit‚Äôs care are also in mortal danger, and they must be kept alive at all costs.

On the surface All Systems Red is just a sci-fi thriller, with some elements of a murder mystery, espionage, and conspiracy. Digging a little deeper there is some depth underneath the casual colloquial prose style. Murderbot. An ominous name for an Artificial Intelligence (AI) that helps humans out in the future. Martha Wells has given us the first installation (a short novel) of Murderbot in All Systems Red. This is a spunky, fun and adventurous little book. It has lots of action and diverse personalities; not the least of which is Murderbot.

Robots and Gender
I'm not sure why, and have been thinking about it for days, but I see Murderbot as a woman. This may be because I am a woman and so identify with the AI directly. It maybe that my bisexual mind just likes boobs; or it may be that I want strong robot AI's to be female because women deserve to be lethal as well. I really don't know. All I know is Murderbot was a woman for me from the first page and they have continued to be a woman in my head. Even though Wells uses they, them pronouns for Murderbot. I'm sure there is an interesting sociological or gender studies paper to be written about what gender readers see Murderbot as. Maybe the beautiful of Murderbot is that you can give them the traits you want to be gender neutral or not.

Action Packed
All Systems Red is full of adventurous action. From the opening page where we learn of the mining expedition Murderbot is on to the closing chapter in which a most unusual event occurs; All Systems Red delivers a quick read if nothing else. I really enjoyed the action. Although at times I did feel like the plot was a little complex (or maybe how the companies were structured was the problem) to follow. But it didn't really matter at the end of the day because the only important thing is Murderbot.

Overall - Ready for the Next One!
I already have the second book 'Artificial Condition' on the go. At less than 200 pages these short novels are fun, fast and helping me reach my (very behind) 2018 reading goal. Because Wells has kept all of the Murderbot stories short it doesn't hurt to try it out and see for yourself if it's your thing. I like them and could certainly see myself revisiting them for a reread break at times because they are quick and easy.

Murderbot is a security android, tasked with keeping an exploratory team safe. The humans think Murderbot is just a mindless robot like the rest of the security androids. They couldn‚Äôt be more wrong.


Plot-wise, it‚Äôs quite straight forward but solid and intensely gripping. It reminds me a bit of the Riddick movie Pitch Black for all the right reasons. With a group of humans being stalked and a not entirely human killer protecting them from harm. Especially with the way some humans look at the one person who can protect them, eyes full of doubt and suspicion. Afraid of the unknown basically. Though the book is much more character-driven rather than action-packed. And the plot is actually elevated by Murderbot wanting to protect its humans, while also trying to hide the fact that it broke free from its corporate limitations.


The biggest attraction of this story is without a shred of a doubt the protagonist. The character of Murderbot is just an absolute homerun and it‚Äôs so easy to fall in love with this android. Murderbot might be an android and it‚Äôs definitely not entirely human in more ways than one, but it is also very relatable. Murderbot is pretty much an introverted teenager. It appears to be wasting time in its formative years by watching tons of mindless entertainment. But it‚Äôs actually trying to figure out who or what it wants to be in life. It does so by secluding itself. So it can experiment with what it‚Äôs like to be its own boss, instead of always just blindly following the orders it has been given.


The ending doesn‚Äôt give us readers the most obvious satisfying climax to the story. But maybe that‚Äôs a good thing. And in its defense, it‚Äôs without a doubt a solid ending and it fits perfectly with Murderbot‚Äôs character arc.


It‚Äôs about an introverted robot with a mind of its own. What‚Äôs not to like? Easy recommendation.

Well this is a really pointless review. If you like Science Fiction you have heard of this already, and you have either read it or you are going to read it. It's been popping up in all my recommendations for a while now, and with cover art as awesome as that, it really was only a matter of time.

Now, full disclosure: the one reason I was initially skittish about reading this, is because it is a novella. That shouldn't matter, and it likely doesn't (to just about everybody else), but for some reason I have always preferred novel length stories.

Anyway, that's neither here nor there. This book made a significant impact. It was nominated for just about every Science Fiction award you can quickly think of and it won the Hugo, Nebula and Locus awards (for best novella).

And yes, it is totally worth it. This story of a security bot who has hacked its own governing module (thereby giving itself access to free choice) is fun and moves really quickly. There are some cool reveals about "Murderbot" and its past, as well as an intriguing final act that will have you wanting to read the sequels.

I have subtracted a star because the story is sparse on detail and limited in scope (some reviewers have been likening it to a YA novel, but it is also perhaps in order to keep it to novella length). It reads quick as hell though, so even if it isn't your cup of tea it won't be time wasted. That said, it's hard for me to imagine anybody not enjoying this.

I'm glad to see there are sequels - although I do hope that at least some of them are full novels.

I did not care for this book.
Based on the book description it should have been right up my ally, but I was really disappointed.

The book seems to get great reviews by other readers, however I don't think this is a true reflection of this book. I think that most readers either a) never finished the book, or b) simply did not want to waste another minute writing a review of the book.

So my fellow readers, if you are considering this book please read this review as I think it will give you a more balanced view of the book.

My biggest problem is the characters - And there are quite a few of them. The sad thing is, that I cant even tell you how many characters there are. I estimate that there are 6 - 10 characters in the book, but they are all so bland and frankly non-essential to the plot, that I could not tell them apart. You get little to no information about them other than a name and a team function. There are also some interpersonal relations between them, but again they do not matter for the plot at all.

The plot itself is thin, and only works if you care about the characters, and since I didn't, the plot did not work for me at all.

The world building is basically non-existent. Lots of references to other places and cultures, but no info on them. Its basically just all footnotes.

I am not usually this harsh in my reviews, and always try to give the book the benefit of the doubt, but in this case I simply don't think this book is worth your time.

If you are looking for a book in this style with a robot / cyborg as the protagonist, I would suggest you consider these books instead:

- The Alchemy of Stone by Ekaterina Sedia
- Cinder by Marissa Meyer (Love warning)

Or if you are just looking for an awesome catheter driven sci-fi book please consider The Long Way to a Small, Angry Planet by Becky Chambers. One of my all-time favourite books.

I hope this review was useful to you.

Murderbot, a cyborg that was able to hack into its governor module and gain independence, by not having to follow company commands, hates dealing with humans. It just wants to do its job and spend hours watching soap-operas. Unfortunately for Murderbot, the mission it's on gets exceptionally hectic, and it has to sacrifice its precious alone time to deal with the messy problems of messy humans. Throughout this debacle, Murderbot notices that these humans actually care for its well-being, and don't see it as a purely disposable machine that can be easily replaced. Even more shocking is the fact that Murderbot might just be slowly reciprocating these feelings back.

This is a short SF novella that is very much loved by the SF community, so I went into it with high expectations. However, it seems like I've found myself treading the dangerous "Unpopular Opinionland" with this one. This novella didn't elicit any feelings in me. Murderbot didn't really feel like a cyborg, and felt like just another grumpy old human who slowly softens up. I had trouble suspending my disbelief and convincing myself that a machine is capable of being this human like. The plot was utterly forgettable for me, and as I write this review after about 10 days of finishing the novella, I am truly struggling to remember what even happened. Perhaps I should have listened to the audiobook? Maybe hearing the narration might have immersed me more into this story... But as it stands, I can't really seem to see anything special here.

I still want to give this series more of a try though, so I will be reading the next installment, or perhaps listening to it, hoping Murderbot will grow on me eventually.

4.5 Stars for Narration by Kevin R. Free
4.5 Stars for Murderbot
4 Stars for Plot

One of the beautiful aspects about words is that you can say a lot with very little or a lot. You can make a simple sentence to have the effect of a loaded gun. You can describe with a thousand words and strip away all mystery from the unknown.

I started my re-read of the Murderbot Diaries because I'm rather excited about the new release coming out in a few days. Back in 2018, I had to try several times to get into this story. It took a while to snag my interest but it didn't take long for me to become a fan of Murderbot, the cranky introvert.

I have a couple of personal themes that are repeating in my reading in 2020:

- Rediscovering the joy of stories told in different styles of simple to complex weaving of characters, setting and plot. It's not enough for me to jump around in genres to keep my brain actively involved in books. I also need different writing styles, voices & themes to keep engaged.

- Finding comfort in re-reading books that I have loved or eyed with mild disgruntlement due to the work involved in reading it. I don't need to love a character or the core plot in order to enjoy a story or writing. I do need to be engaged in some manner to read the story from start to finish but it doesn't always have to be instant love. Sometimes, I will love the "how/why" behind the writing more than the story written.

- True to Character: For the past year, I've come to have more fun with re-reads due to how well the author has created a world & character and they stay true to the core aspects from start to finish. Sometimes, it's harder to see or appreciate the humor or nuances that are given from the start because I'm not familiar with the world/character. Going back in gives me the chance to see all the details put into place with more awareness. I love seeing how events/etc are established in a small detail or pivotal event and how it impacts the whole series.

All Systems Red
The first couple of times I listened to the story, I thought the story was cool but a little light in areas that could have made it more. That's still true. In this round, I love how there's no wasted words. Each one was there for a reason/s and the whole story is very active. There is a steady progression of thoughts, ideas and actions taken from start to finish. It's much more obvious on the re-read.

10/03/2018 Notes:

I didn't really have any expectations when I started this book. I knew that a lot of my friends like the series and the latest addition was published yesterday. The beginning was a little murky and I wasn't sure what was going on, but details for the setting and characters became clearer as I listened. Murderbot definitely has a personality and it's fun to watch it's evolution.

What a great read! I wasn't sure what to make of Martha Wells's All Systems Red at first, but Murderbot drew me in quickly. A construct made from cloned human material and robotic parts, Murderbot was created to provide security for various human clients. But Murderbot has a secret: it has managed to hack its governor unit (the component that forces it to obey commands), and while still pretending to be submissive to its human clients, has taken up watching countless hours of TV shows in its spare time. In the process, Murderbot has developed its own ideas about the nature of humanity and free will. When the humans it's been rented out to simultaneously come to terrible danger and start treating it as a person, Murderbot becomes both protective and horribly uncomfortable.

(I should note: for some reason I kept reading Murderbot as 'she', but I don't think there's any evidence of that in the book itself, so I'm clearly introducing some of my own reader bias here. Martha Wells has commented on this subject and made it clear that Murderbot does not see itself as having a gender.)

Overall, the story is engaging and well told, and always at the centre is this entity that largely can't stand to be around humans and yet is gradually becoming more and more what we would call human, while Murderbot itself would rather pretty much any other word. That alone is worth the couple of hours to read the book. If there was any disappointment for me with All Systems Red it was only that the climax itself felt a bit rushed and ended a bit flat for me. The epilogue quickly brings back what makes Murderbot so fascinating, however, and I'm keen to read the next instalment.

I've never read novellas before, but lately I'm starting to really enjoy the form, and All Systems Red is a great one to start with if you're thinking of jumping in.

Many books are written about the idea of an android becoming sentient. Not many of those books are good.

This one rocks!

If you know about an assassin droid HK-47 from the Star Wars universe and you liked him and his twisted sense of sarcasm - you will love every second (err.. page?) of this book. If not, it doesn't really matter.

Not so much cynical sarcasm here as much as a healthy dose of android humor. I leave it up to you to decide how much exactly is a healthy dose. I had a blast.

So, the story:

People go to planetary exploration missions or just colonize those planets. People like doing that.

Indigenous life on those planets, however, generally doesn't. Indigenous life can be dangerous to the abovementioned human brave hearts.

To minimize the loss of life, The Company supplies explorers with security droids in addition to ships, supplies and general logistics.

On the other hand, to minimize the loss of money, explorers (mostly their employers) often sign up for the services of the lowest bidder in the security business.

If you haven't guessed it already, this is where our friendly droid comes in. All security units come with a Governor module installed which, among other things, prevents the android from going berserk and horribly murdering the exploration party he's tasked with protecting.

Of course, being made of cheap parts, his Governor module is also made of crap and allows the android to hack and override it. He doesn't horribly murder his exploration party (at least not yet :) but he does call himself MurderBot because of an event from his past. That knowledge would raise quite a few eyebrows if those pesky humans with their million questions only knew about it.

This is a good, action-packed story about a self-aware, socially-awkward android who just wants to be left alone. But that's not going to happen.

Oh, and body parts will fly left and right - both human and android alike.

I'm fairly certain I did not actually buy this book but it was given to me for review. Whoever you are, thank you for this gem! I'm putting the sequel high on my to-do list.

The story is gripping and narration just perfect. I shed a tear or two after realizing the book is barely over 3 hours long. I need a sequel!

Not 10 days after reading the book, I saw the tram in Amsterdam heading for Murderbot Station. I had to take a picture xD

Well, here's the most charming unreliable narrator I've come across in ages: a security bot that has secretly hacked its way to autonomy and refers to itself by the name of Murderbot. Contrary to expectation, Murderbot prefers to keep to itself and binge-watch serials in between half-assing its job as security detail for scientists surveying a new planet.

Things go dramatically wrong with giant toothy tunneling things, and then wrong in more troubling ways - autopilot failures, map inaccuracies, sudden silence from a sister survey team. Having hacked its governor module, Murderbot doesn't have to do anything, but it might just be able to save the day. If it wants. If it likes its humans enough. But whoa, feelings? Not Murderbot's cuppa.

So, I'm awkward with actual humans. It's not paranoia about my hacked governor module, and it's not them; it's me. I know I'm a horrifying murderbot, and they know it, and it makes both of us nervous, which makes me even more nervous. Also, if I'm not in the armor then it's because I'm wounded and one of my organic parts may fall off and plop on the floor at any moment and no one wants to see that.

All Systems Red is an unusual coming-of-age (er, sentience?) story whose charm lies mostly in its quirky bot main character. Murderbot is indifferent to its job, feels utter contempt for the company that owns it ("we're cheaply produced and we suck. This was an excellent sci-fi novella told from a very unique point of view: a socially anxious, introverted murderbot (its term, not mine).

One way sci-fi stories, especially length constrained novellas, can fail is putting in too much exposition in building the world and not enough attention spent on getting a good story on the page. Wells avoids this by only relating what is important about the world as needed and not worrying about such things as: how did Humanity spread to the stars? Why are corporations so powerful? Why are ancient aliens artifacts and ruins so prized? Is the Simpsons still running?

Overall, I enjoyed this and thought that Martha Wells provided a fun romp but left some meat on the philosophical questions. The protagonist in this story is a robot, whose only function is to provide protection for professionals. In the hierarchy of robot protectors, it is towards the middle in job grade. While, not as impressive as some models that are used for wealthy clients who demand a more bombastic approach it also is not so porous that it is rendered useless. Though thought to be devoid of a personality, this particular robot has a proclivity for soap operas (Sanctuary Moon) and solitude. Without giving away too much of the plot, this robot has fundamentally changed its' proscribed use but this change has fascinating repercussions. The blending of human and machine though a frequent device in literature takes a unique turn in this read. Though this story can stand alone, I am curious to see how Ms. Wells will continue the trajectory of the series. When I am need of another sci-fi hit I will gladly pick up more books in this delightful series.

On a very distant planet, way out in the universe ‚Äî our protagonist is escorting a team of human scientists, whom have been tasked with scouring the surface of planets in order to gain as much scientific data as possible. The self labelled ‚Äòmurdebot‚Äô ‚Äî an android made up of the latest tech & software ‚Äî has hacked its own module, the module that ensures it is self-aware and not completely subservient to the humans as it should be ‚Äî creating a fun, engaging, easy to follow consciousness where the android is trying to discover who it really is and where it allegiances lie.

Then when a neighbouring mission goes bad, things get serious and it is here where All systems red goes from fun to ferociously-addictive, with twists and turns, black comedy, hopelessness and at its core the central message permeates every plot point, absorbing every paragraph due to it being the heartbeat of all human or non-human consciousness ‚Äî The search for self, identity, meaning and spirituality, the walk of life!

Murderbot ‚Äî as discovered this time round, that is read so well by Kevin Free & also brilliantly dramatised in a new late 2023 release ‚Äî thanks to its magnificent, one-of-a-kind self-consciousness and subsequent rationale, created by its hacking of its own system ‚Äî is truly a paradox and paradigm, that also has an insatiable appetite for killing ‚Äî this android is no robot! It‚Äôs self-deprecating, has a roller-coasting mental state that feels more human than any of the humans in the story, and becomes the near-perfect flawed protagonist you just cannot help but root for with legitimate passion and fervour ‚Äî Even upon a recent quick re-read before I tackle Book Two and beyond, it was paramountly evident that Martha Wells world of high-tech, space madness is of a certain genius that perhaps has yet to be fully appreciated for the creative brilliance it deserves.

What a fun SF novella. I bought this totally on a whim a few days ago when it's on sale since the synopsis and the reviews look promising. Different with other books languishing in my TBR shelf, I decided to read it right away (a record!) since the Kindle sample grabbed my attention.

It was so funny, if you like dry humour. The snarky, TV-series-bingewatcher 'SecUnit construct' with a penchant of saving its 'humans' because it actually cared. Well, just a bit. Not too much, since it did not even care who they were, or barely read his clients' personnel files (because it needed the storage space for its series collection LOL).

Of course, the Murderbot - as it preferred to call itself - had some other motives for its actions. Still very rational and it knew what it wanted. It is not a lovey dovey relationship with the humans, it even tried really hard not to communicate too much. As an introvert myself, I definitely symphatize with the bot. I too need time to recharge and be alone whenever I have had too many human interaction. And I too, obviously, am crazy about TV series. So, there you go. I have not read too many SF with a POV from a robot so this one is definitely memorable.

All in all, the novella is sharp, action-packed, has straightforward plot (because why not), no useless space for unnecessary world building, and of course, the characterization of the slightly depressed bot is marvelous - if you like Marvin from the Hitchhiker's novels, you'll like Murderbot. Kate Elliot mentioned in her blurb that All Systems Red is "clever, inventive, brutal when it needs to be, and compassionate without ever being sentimental." I could not agree more.

This novella has an airy tone that ends up delivering a punchy catharsis. The unnamed SecUnit that calls itself Murderbot is self-contained and wary while it hides that it disabled the governor unit that is supposed to control its actions. So it doesn't have to follow orders but it also doesn't want that fact discovered. So while the adventure/mystery story unfolds at a fast pace an undercurrent of autonomy and identity plays out in the background.

This undercurrent is highlighted by the group of humans Murderbot is working for/with. They're well-meaning and determined and lead by a woman with strong convictions and a quick mind. So when they discover that it is ungoverned, their reactions range from intrusively sympathetic to actively suspicious, giving the story scope (however slight) to explore those buried themes.

I thought at first that the action/mystery dominated that under-theme but I think Wells ends up using that to build the connection-through-adversity that forms the framework for the eventual resolution. Which delivers that punchy catharsis that brought me all the feelz.

So I'm giving this an unmitigated five stars, because I'm all about the feelz. But I'll note that the distance between underlying theme (autonomy and identity) and the story frame (action/mystery) in such a short work is enough that it'll be disconcerting to those who want more of one or the other. And I'll agree with Tadiana that the characterization for the rest of the crew is shallow. But I didn't care. I was all about the Murderbot/Mensah connection and that ending slew me.

Well that was a fun little diversion. And by little, I mean LITTLE! This is, hands down, the shortest book I've read all year. And also probably the easiest read I've done all year. Given my penchant for reading large and/or heady books, this one was pretty much a "blink and you'll miss it" deviation for me. It was also our book club pick following the behemoth that was Brandon Sanderson's The Way of Kings, and we chose it because it was an easy read, which we felt was necessary after wading through the 1000+ pages of TWoK.

So what did I think of All Systems Red? Well, it was...good. That's about the best I can come up with at the moment. I loved the idea of a rogue Security bot that hacked its own governor, stopped caring about the corporate mission, and decided to basically be a TV junkie. And the fact that it refers to itself as Murderbot was just priceless. But outside of those concepts, the story just didn't really move me like I hoped it would.

Part if this is, I'm sure, due to the brevity of the tale. There's not a lot of room for character arcs or deep plotting in a story this short. And I get it...it's not supposed to be a monster story. This is popcorn entertainment, and it achieves that goal rather well. But, that being said, I still was left feeling a little cold after reading All Systems Red. Nobody really gets any backstory or context, the people in the tale are essentially just random people who are assigned various archetypes and behaviors to stand out. I never got much of a visual of any of them. As for Murderbot, while admired the snarky way in which it narrated its tale, I still wanted to know more about it, and this never really came to pass.

Another thing that took away from my enjoyment is the way in which the narrative unfolds. I've read several books where the storytelling was...incidental at best. But All Systems Red takes the cake. Everything, and I mean EVERYTHING, was just kind of half-explained or defined. From the action to the locations to the characters themselves, nothing is written in much detail. In fact, the action scenes were comprised mostly of passages that read something like "I ran at it while shooting my projectile weapon. It was shooting at me at the same time. I got hit a few times, but I managed to find a vital area on my opponent and take it down." And...that's it. The problem with writing like this is it robs the story of any sense of drama or suspense. It's all so...casual. And that casual writing makes the narrative casual as well, which doesn't help to engage the reader as much.

Because this is a short novella, we jump from sequence to sequence pretty quickly, but even on things that I felt should have been given more weight, Martha Wells just kinda glosses over them. Not having read any of her other works, I can't say if this is just how she writes, or if she had to constrain herself to keep the story short & sweet. Again, I wanted more.

But it's not all bad! Murderbot is a fun narrator, and carries the first person POV tale quite well. I enjoyed the snark, the sarcasm, and the flippancy in which it viewed most situations it found itself in. I loved how anti-social Murderbot was, and how it really just wanted to be left alone to watch its video entertainment...aka soap operas.

The overall concept is also rather cool, but I feel that this could have been far more impactful as either a full-length novel or a larger novella. I wanted more heft with my tale, and I never received that. But I can see the potential here, and given that this is the first in a series of books, I think Martha Wells can certainly take this character in interesting directions. The ending of this one opens up all sorts of possibilities, and I'd like to see what is next for Murderbot.

It was also our book club pick following the behemoth that was Brandon Sanderson's The Way of Kings, and we chose it because it was an easy read, which we felt was necessary after wading through the 1000+ pages of TWoK.

So what did I think of All Systems Red? Well, it was...good. That's about the best I can come up with at the moment. I loved the idea of a rogue Security bot that hacked its own governor, stopped caring about the corporate mission, and decided to basically be a TV junkie. And the fact that it refers to itself as Murderbot was just priceless. But outside of those concepts, the story just didn't really move me like I hoped it would.

Part if this is, I'm sure, due to the brevity of the tale. There's not a lot of room for character arcs or deep plotting in a story this short. And I get it...it's not supposed to be a monster story. This is popcorn entertainment, and it achieves that goal rather well. But, that being said, I still was left feeling a little cold after reading All Systems Red. Nobody really gets any backstory or context, the people in the tale are essentially just random people who are assigned various archetypes and behaviors to stand out. I never got much of a visual of any of them. As for Murderbot, while admired the snarky way in which it narrated its tale, I still wanted to know more about it, and this never really came to pass.

Another thing that took away from my enjoyment is the way in which the narrative unfolds. I've read several books where the storytelling was...incidental at best. But All Systems Red takes the cake. Everything, and I mean EVERYTHING, was just kind of half-explained or defined. From the action to the locations to the characters themselves, nothing is written in much detail. In fact, the action scenes were comprised mostly of passages that read something like "I ran at it while shooting my projectile weapon. It was shooting at me at the same time. I got hit a few times, but I managed to find a vital area on my opponent and take it down." And...that's it. The problem with writing like this is it robs the story of any sense of drama or suspense. It's all so...casual. And that casual writing makes the narrative casual as well, which doesn't help to engage the reader as much.

Because this is a short novella, we jump from sequence to sequence pretty quickly, but even on things that I felt should have been given more weight, Martha Wells just kinda glosses over them. Not having read any of her other works, I can't say if this is just how she writes, or if she had to constrain herself to keep the story short & sweet. Again, I wanted more.

But it's not all bad! Murderbot is a fun narrator, and carries the first person POV tale quite well. I enjoyed the snark, the sarcasm, and the flippancy in which it viewed most situations it found itself in. I loved how anti-social Murderbot was, and how it really just wanted to be left alone to watch its video entertainment...aka soap operas.

The overall concept is also rather cool, but I feel that this could have been far more impactful as either a full-length novel or a larger novella. I wanted more heft with my tale, and I never received that. But I can see the potential here, and given that this is the first in a series of books, I think Martha Wells can certainly take this character in interesting directions. The ending of this one opens up all sorts of possibilities, and I'd like to see what is next for Murderbot.

It must figure out humans and how to act robot to keep his sentience a secret, not least because it had disabled certain modules in order to preserve its exercise of free will and a mortal‚Äôs sense of self-preservation amongst others. At the root, it now has to grapple with having opinions and feelings which necessitates understanding the nuances of human interactions including facial expressions and reading between the lines in order preserve its secret and later, to express his opinions and cooperate with humans to investigate possible breaches, criminal or fraudulent activities. In other words, Murderbot demonstrates both primary and secondary thinking by understanding learned behaviours, social conventions and personal goals as it deduces human and corporate motives.

Murderbot feels beyond basic feelings and emotions which extends to disgust, betrayal and even a fiddly form of empathy. Its relationship with humans can be described as a form of reverse anthropomorphism‚Äîhumans don‚Äôt know how to categorise it and thus, the appropriate way to act around it while the murderbot tries to blend in with the humans as an android with hilarious results. Readers could then decide at what point a person or a robot becomes a machine and ceases to be human or vice versa, along with the ethical implications.

Martha Wells‚Äô novella about a disaffected robot struggling with identity issues is like a set of Russian nesting dolls: there are stories within stories. It's an impressive accomplishment and Wells says more in 144 pages than most authors do in their 1,000-page trilogies.

The main story arc is a high-octane adventure about a sentient robot assigned to protect a group of scientists on their survey of a planet from sabotage, man-eating wildlife, and armed invaders from another company determined to take control of the planet at any cost. But the SecUnit assigned to protect the small survey group is a rogue agent with some serious psychological issues‚Ä¶MURDERBOT.

I could have become a mass murderer after I hacked my governor module, but then I realized I could access the combined feed of entertainment channels carried on the company satellites. It had been well over 35,000 hours or so since then, with still not much murdering. As a heartless killing machine, I was a terrible failure.

Murderbot is the AI version of the sensitive loner in high school. The edgy introvert who would rather read Jack Kerouac than attend social events. Lightning fast and armed with energy cannons, Murderbot is a fighting machine that doesn‚Äôt want to fight. It‚Äôs a reluctant hero who would rather be left alone to watch media, but it feels a responsibility to get the hapless humans to safety. Like so many readers, I related to Murderbot from page one and loved its sarcastic sense of humor. Despite its preference for mainlining galactic soap operas, there are plenty of gun fights and last-minute rescues for readers who want a fun adventure story.

I knew I could kill everyone on the hopper, even with a blown hip joint and one working arm. So I grabbed the hand weapon on the seat, turned it toward my chest, and pulled the trigger.

The second story arc is about free will, personhood, and the future of AI. SecUnits like Murderbot are leased out by their corporate owners to protect human clients; they are considered property rather than people. While robots can be citizens in some territories outside corporate space, they are second-class citizens at best who are required to have human guardians. Sentience and the desire for self-determination are not sufficient for bots to be free or equal to humans. The author contrasts Murderbot‚Äôs experience with Gurathin, a human cyborg on the survey team. While both Murderbot and Gurathin are part organic and part machine, Gurathin is a citizen with all the attendant rights, simply because he was born human. Murderbot was built in a lab, so it despite its intelligence, cloned human tissue, and the ability to have feelings, it is considered a machine no different than a PC. Murderbot is trying to decide who it wants to be and how it wants to live in a society that doesn't allow it to make either of those decisions.

It‚Äôs wrong to think of a construct as half bot, half human. That makes it sound like the halves are discrete‚Ä¶as opposed to the reality, which was that I was one whole confused entity.

Finally, and least developed, is the story arc about the future of humanity after we colonize space. Given the page limits of a novella, Wells just sketches in brief outlines of humanity and governance across various worlds. The book takes place in the Corporate Rim, where multi-planet companies rule and money is the only thing that matters. Murderbot blandly notes that the company that leased it to the survey group would certainly take bribes from an opposing survey group and says the only reason the company wouldn‚Äôt conspire to murder its clients is because the death payouts would be too high. Meanwhile, the survey group is from a democratic planet called Perseverance in non-corporate space, which values human rights, decency, and the rule of law. Bots have limited rights under those laws, and the survey group wants Murderbot to return with them to their liberal planet. Basically, you have unchecked capitalism vs. democratic socialism as co-existing philosophies in space, although it's unclear how that happened.

I‚Äôm docking half a star because I enjoy complex world-building (e.g., John Scalzi) and would have loved to read more about the different star systems. I also felt that most of the secondary characters were underdeveloped. I wish Wells had written a full-length novel that fleshed out the characters, especially Mensah, the courageous and compassionate team leader who bonds most closely with Murderbot. But these are mere quibbles; the book is fantastic and I have already started reading the next novella in the series.

4.5 heartwarming stars.

Murderbot is the AI version of the sensitive loner in high school. The edgy introvert who would rather read Jack Kerouac than attend social events. Lightning fast and armed with energy cannons, Murderbot is a fighting machine that doesn‚Äôt want to fight. It‚Äôs a reluctant hero who would rather be left alone to watch media, but it feels a responsibility to get the hapless humans to safety. Like so many readers, I related to Murderbot from page one and loved its sarcastic sense of humor. Despite its preference for mainlining galactic soap operas, there are plenty of gun fights and last-minute rescues for readers who want a fun adventure story.

I knew I could kill everyone on the hopper, even with a blown hip joint and one working arm. So I grabbed the hand weapon on the seat, turned it toward my chest, and pulled the trigger.

The second story arc is about free will, personhood, and the future of AI. SecUnits like Murderbot are leased out by their corporate owners to protect human clients; they are considered property rather than people. While robots can be citizens in some territories outside corporate space, they are second-class citizens at best who are required to have human guardians. Sentience and the desire for self-determination are not sufficient for bots to be free or equal to humans. The author contrasts Murderbot‚Äôs experience with Gurathin, a human cyborg on the survey team. While both Murderbot and Gurathin are part organic and part machine, Gurathin is a citizen with all the attendant rights, simply because he was born human. Murderbot was built in a lab, so it despite its intelligence, cloned human tissue, and the ability to have feelings, it is considered a machine no different than a PC. Murderbot is trying to decide who it wants to be and how it wants to live in a society that doesn't allow it to make either of those decisions.

It‚Äôs wrong to think of a construct as half bot, half human. That makes it sound like the halves are discrete‚Ä¶as opposed to the reality, which was that I was one whole confused entity.

Finally, and least developed, is the story arc about the future of humanity after we colonize space. Given the page limits of a novella, Wells just sketches in brief outlines of humanity and governance across various worlds. The book takes place in the Corporate Rim, where multi-planet companies rule and money is the only thing that matters. Murderbot blandly notes that the company that leased it to the survey group would certainly take bribes from an opposing survey group and says the only reason the company wouldn‚Äôt conspire to murder its clients is because the death payouts would be too high. Meanwhile, the survey group is from a democratic planet called Perseverance in non-corporate space, which values human rights, decency, and the rule of law. Bots have limited rights under those laws, and the survey group wants Murderbot to return with them to their liberal planet. Basically, you have unchecked capitalism vs. democratic socialism as co-existing philosophies in space, although it's unclear how that happened.

I‚Äôm docking half a star because I enjoy complex world-building (e.g., John Scalzi) and would have loved to read more about the different star systems. I also felt that most of the secondary characters were underdeveloped. I wish Wells had written a full-length novel that fleshed out the characters, especially Mensah, the courageous and compassionate team leader who bonds most closely with Murderbot. But these are mere quibbles; the book is fantastic and I have already started reading the next novella in the series.

4.5 heartwarming stars.

I started listening to All Systems Red on Scribd with the hopes of passing some time listening to something fun and simple while doing kitchen chores. Boy, was I wrong. I ended up not only cleaning the kitchen, reorganizing the pantry, fridge, cooking dinner, and meals for the next day in the hopes of listening to as much of this as possible before having to put it away for the night. It is compulsive and addictive read. Once you start reading it, it is so short and exciting you will not want to stop till you get to the end.

All Systems Red is a perfect and tidy story. When I say tidy, it isn't derogatory. Novellas have to get a lot done in a short amount of time. The author needs to convey thought, history, emotion, narrative, and plot progression. So all of the choices the author makes need to be concise and tidy. In Martha Wells, All Sytems Red, she created an exceptional character in Murderbot, Murderbot being the name he calls himself. He is cynical, confused, and courageous but more than anything, Murderbot has very human emotions. This character works quite well within the context of a novella because the reading audience has a cultural dialog regarding machines with human emotions, i.e., The Terminator. There isn't a lot of groundwork to be laid, we already have a feel for what this scenario could look like. Murderbot is an artificial life form with organic components, and these components work in tandem with its artificial ones to create the perfect killing machine.

How life works for the Murderbot is that he is deployed on contract through his host company, The Company. In the first installment of the quadrilogy of short stories, Murderbot is protecting and defending a group of scientists and geographers on an inhospitable planet. Murderbot hacks his mainframe to start making independent choices aside from is company programming. Most of his decisions consist of which type of soap opera to watch on the entertainment channels available at his outpost. However, when another outpost on the same planet gets attacked, Murderbot needs to step in to protect the scientists that he has become attached to. What plays out over the brief story is exciting scenes, great dialog (both internal and external), and an excellent plot jump to the next novella. I loved this, and it is easily understood why the author received so many well-deserved accolades. It is funny and enjoyable.

This book belongs to one of my favorite SF sub-genres - sentient AI. Scientists and philosophers should have come up with better answers for the problem of conscious AI at least a decade ago, but well, here we are. In the domains of SF. Again.

Is organicity a necessary and sufficient condition for consciousness? Now Cartesian dualism will give you a solid no and I agree, but when it comes to AI, I've heard people arguing that AI cannot be 'conscious' because the notion of 'I' necessitates cognitive acts that are conscious and not merely computational. I'll ignore the dangers of such a reduction for now because murderbot, our protagonist from this series, has hacked their governer module. Their (Really, they have an organic bodysuit but they don't seem to think much of it and they never state their preferred pronouns in this book, I doubt they have one) acts are not merely computational.

Murderbot has very human traits - social awkwardness, rage, passivity, compassion and a weird possessiveness. But I'm also wary of the idea that anything alien must correspond to human-ness in order to ascribe a notion of subjectivity to it, as though consciousness is merely a human attribute. And this is where Becky Chambers does really well, I love how she writes about AI and alien species. With this author, I'm still a little cautious.

However, it was very enjoyable and light. I'm fairly confident I'll read the rest of the series. Probably over the next few weekends when I need a break from non-fiction.

This short science fiction book is a gem. I can understand how this could be considered a young adult book. The plot is straight-forward and a bit space-operish. The main character's psychology is what makes it a fascinating novella for adults.

The story is told in the first person by the protagonist, self-named Murderbot. He/she is a robot. They were made as a security guard. (Should I use They/Them for Murderbot? Or only with 100% humans? I'm new to using the new pronoun methodology.) There are three types of beings in this world: humans, augmented humans (like the Million Dollar Man), and robots. The robots are primarily mechanical but still include many human parts. Maybe this is why Murderbot so easily became sentient when they hacked their governor component.

Before Murderbot became self-aware they were ordered to kill many humans and now feels bad about it. Not that Murderbot likes humans. They'd rather sit in the cargo hold watching television than mingling with humans. If they are forced to communicate face-to-face with a human they prefer doing it with their face shield down; or turn facing into a corner to avoid eye contact.

The narrative is very funny. Murderbot thinks most humans are dimwits. They use self-depreciating humor too. If you think the astronauts' inner dialog in Project Hail Mary and The Martian by Andy Weir is funny you probably will find this humorous too.

I will be re-reading this sometime for pure pleasure.

Earning a solid 4.5 ‚≠êÔ∏è rating thanks to the aforementioned narrative, this novella is an extremely economically efficient, sharp-punching-black-eye-shining gem in the world of speculative fiction, science fiction, space opera & to be honest, fiction full-stop. Wells introduces us to a world where artificial constructs, known as "SecUnits," are non-autonomously tasked with security and protection, for their human clients. However, the protagonist here ‚Äî Murderbot ‚Äî is not your typical SecUnit, thanks to some ‚Äî very cleverly designed ‚Äî software flaws that remove his inability to use free-will. With a wry sense of humor, introspective tendencies, and a secret desire for freedom, Murderbot truly transcends the typical, monotonous robot archetype to develop into a loveably intelligent, moving & deeply relatable character. It is through Murderbot's narrative voice that we explore themes of identity, autonomy, and the blurred lines between human and machine.

The novella's pacing is close to impeccable. Wells keeps the tension riotously taut, using concise prose that effortlessly carries the reader through the story. The action sequences are adrenaline-fueled, but what truly sets "All Systems Red" apart is its ability to balance intense moments with moments of quiet reflection. Murderbot's internal struggles and musings on the nature of freedom add depth to the story, elevating it beyond a mere action-packed adventure.

The world-building in "All Systems Red" is another standout aspect. The author crafts a richly detailed future where corporate interests clash with the desire for knowledge and exploration. The various planets and habitats are vividly described, immersing the reader in a universe that feels both familiar and alien. Wells also delves into the complexities of interstellar politics and the ethical dilemmas posed by advanced AI, adding layers of depth to the narrative.

One of the novella's strengths lies in its character dynamics. Murderbot's interactions with its human clients, particularly with the scientist Dr. Mensah, are a highlight of the story. The evolving relationships and the growth of trust between these characters are beautifully portrayed. It's a testament to Martha Wells & I cannot wait to delve further into the speculative world of Murderbot & it‚Äôs undoubtedly entertaining, violently fascinating tales!

This book was captivating from the first sentence


"I could have become a mass murderer after I hacked my governor module, but then I realized I could access the feed of entertainment channels carried on the company satellites..."


I'm a big fan of Martha Well's Books of the Raksura series (The Cloud Roads) so it took a while to build up the courage to read her more acclaimed Murderbot novella. All that hesitation for naught! This book is so different and it is so good

Murderbot is a Security Unit that is contractually added to research team's expeditions. It is owned by a parent company and rented out, where it's in charge of making sure scientists don't get eaten by fauna in the field. Unfortunately the company, like irl companies, is cheap as hell and leaves people on the field with faulty equipment. Murderbot itself has fallen victim to this before so on its newest mission, hacks its own regulatory module to avoid a repeat of the past.

The novella is full of worldbuilding, and despite the book's small size Wells does a really good job at making this universe come to life.

The star here is Murderbot. It is a hilarious, awkward, relatable character, and the ethics of having a sentient, mixed organic Unit like Murderbot contractually trapped under employers for its entire existence is noted, but not dragged out like you normally deal with these types of scifi

Love love love

Also at one point I put the book down and screamed because I realized:
Books of the Raksura: MC is a creature who is aro and finds acceptance with his long lost people
Murderbot Diaries: MC is a creature who is ace and finds acceptance with a species not its own

In short: I love them your honor

However, this particular Murderbot has highjacked his governor module which is the apparatus that makes him follow orders. Now in his independence, he can download hours and hours of entertainment so that he can watch soap operas all day and not do his job or care about doing his job.

This machine made of a combination of metal and organic components is such a fresh, new creation. He‚Äôs cynical and hilarious. He does his job reluctantly trying to keep the expeditionary team alive so that they can complete a survey on a remote planet. As you might think, things go wrong from the beginning and don‚Äôt seem to let up. There is quite a bit of excitement packed into this swiftly-paced story which is told completely from Murderbot‚Äôs point of view.

It‚Äôs wrong to think of a construct as half bot, half human. It makes it sound like the halves are discrete, like the bot half should want to obey orders and do its job and the human half should want to protect itself and get the hell out of here. As opposed to the reality, which was that I was one whole confused entity, with no idea what I wanted to do. What I should do. What I needed to do.

The sense of urgency just wasn‚Äôt there. Also, you may have noticed, I don‚Äôt care.

When his group of scientists realize he is more than he claims to be, they begin to treat him as one of them. It creates some very socially awkward and touching moments in the novella because this is not how Murderbot is used to being treated. I have been hearing all of the praise and adoration for this novella for just about 5 years now, and despite having had this in my possession for just about as long (thanks, Tor!) I didn't get around to it until I saw that I could listen to the 3-hour audio version from the library. So I snagged it, and listened to it, and enjoyed it very much.

Most of the reviews from my friends remark on how much they identified with Murderbot's introverted, pessimistic, misanthropic jadedness, and I'm no different (and in good company, clearly). I really enjoyed MB's perspective, and being in their head. I can't bring myself to call MB "it". That seems so dehumanizing. Which I know is ironic, since MB isn't a human - but hearing MB called "it" throughout the story really irked me, though I know it was likely intentional. Somehow, it doesn't seem that Martha Wells would have overlooked that aspect in a story about the discovery of sentience and agency and conscience in a previously programmed bio-machine. The human characters learning about this new identity, and learning to trust and accept it, is kinda the whole point. I loved it for that.

But the story outside of those aspects is great too. Exciting and interesting and much room to grow - so I'm very much looking forward to seeing where it does go when I read more of these. Which I definitely will be doing.

I am doing a re-read of the series on audio and thoroughly enjoyed Kevin Free's narration work in his phlegmatic tone and great timing narrating Murderbot and the variation he gave the other characters.

My re-listen was as wonderful an experience as my original so I'll leave the words of my original review to speak for me.

After reading so many of my book pal's more than favorable reviews on this one, I had to give it a go. I love sci-fi when the character is a sentient AI, cyborg, robot, etc so this was right up my alley.

From the beginning, I was hooked. Murderbot is owned by a company and is sent out as the security bot for a scientific exploration group on a new planet. They are there to determine if they want to buy into the shares for the planet by testing the natural resources available. It's not long before Murderbot is working hard to keep his little herd of scientists safe from someone bent on sabotaging and maybe killing off their stranded group before the date the company comes back to pick them up. Murderbot is fully in command of himself due to a faulty command module and he has to trick everyone into thinking that all systems are normal.

The wry wit of Murderbot (he did have a mass killing under his belt so why not), his non-human way of looking at things, his addiction and binge-watching of human entertainment vids, and the uncertainty this lethal being has around feelings and acts of goodness from humans who generally treat him like equipment makes for an engaging story.

I found it a great blend of character-driven with action plotting. It was a quick read, but very developed. The stranded with someone out to get them for unknown reasons was a great backdrop to see Murderbot and the isolated scientists interact and learn to work together. I liked that it ended leaving things wide open for what comes next even while wrapping up this first exciting chapter in the story.

Well that was unexpected.

I knew nothing about All Systems Red when I browsed my way to it on Audible, but it's cover art looked okay (albeit a little too polished), it had a sweet little blurb, and it was the perfect length to off-set the monster long books to which I was already listening, so I gave it a shot. Damn glad I did.

All Systems Red is a tasty little morsel that dives straight in to what it means to be human through the question of the autonomy of artificial beings. We're thrown into the first person perspective of Murderbot, a security bot who has hacked out its governing system and made itself a free agent. But Martha Wells doesn't retread old Pinocchio-Replicants-Data territory. Instead, she gives us a being easily distracted by bad TV, a being who finds itself empathizing with its comrades without obsessing over the meaning of it all, a being with clear likes and dislikes, a being able to pity and be pitied, a being much like us. Murderbot just wants to live without having to worry about the deletion of memories, a return to enslavement or the loss of choice. It's a pretty simple being, and a likeable one too.

Martha Wells is tackling one of the future's great ethical conundrums here, and she does it while spinning a kick ass adventure -- not too in-depth, not too intense, just right. Fingers crossed that the series will just get better and better.

Let me just say it: All Systems Red is the introverted, sarcastic, secretly-caring AI murder machine I didn‚Äôt know I needed in my life.

This novella launches the Murderbot Diaries with a sharp elbow to the ribs of typical sci-fi and a quietly broken heart under all the armor plating. Our protagonist‚ÄîMurderbot, a SecUnit with hacked programming and a deep desire to be left alone to binge-watch serial dramas‚Äîhas major antisocial vibes, a dry-as-space-dust sense of humor, and the most reluctant hero energy since Han Solo got dragged into the Rebellion.

Murderbot doesn‚Äôt want to save anyone. It wants to curl up in a cargo container, watch its shows, and avoid eye contact with humans. But, alas, humans are fragile meatbags with feelings, and they keep trying to include it in things. Ugh.

But here‚Äôs the twist: the more the crew treats Murderbot like a person instead of a weapon, the more we see just how human this bot really is‚Äîfull of anxiety, trauma, and an identity crisis buried under layers of sarcasm and armor. And all of it is told in Murderbot‚Äôs first-person narration, which is brilliantly hilarious, often touching, and incredibly relatable to anyone who‚Äôs ever felt awkward at a group meeting.

The plot? Tight and tense. Sabotage, mystery, dead survey teams, and corporate nastiness in space‚Äîall classic ingredients, but served up fresh thanks to the voice guiding us through it.
The pacing? Lightning-fast. Like Murderbot when someone suggests they join a team-building exercise.
The emotional depth? Shockingly deep for a novella about a semi-killer robot that watches space soaps.

In short, All Systems Red is like if Marvin the Paranoid Android got therapy and a plasma cannon. It‚Äôs a story about identity, autonomy, and finding yourself‚Äîeven if you‚Äôre a rogue security unit with no time for your feelings, thank you very much.

Why will I continue the series?
Because:
‚úîÔ∏è AI with anxiety and attitude? Check.
‚úîÔ∏è Humor that actually made me laugh out loud? Check.
‚úîÔ∏è A genuinely compelling plot with heart and tension? Check.
‚úîÔ∏è Murderbot. Just‚Ä¶ Murderbot.

Would recommend to:

Sci-fi fans

Introverts

People with anxiety

Anyone who‚Äôs ever whispered ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to be perceived‚Äù and then saved the day anyway

2025: this was so fun to read again on my third or fourth trip back to this opening volume-- it still may be my favorite of the series. Just what I wanted to unwind at the end of a busy month.

This time, I had the recent Apple TV adaptation on the brain; I was worried that the artistic choices there would override my own impressions, but it was much less so than I had anticipated. My image of Mensah has moved a bit, but book!Murderbot speaks in longer sentences than the pithy and rapid-fire delivery on the show, so the book's "accent" took over most of the time after a few pages of back-and-forth. There's also more dark comedy around the edges in a way that really works for me.

The show does some things quite well, particularly in the strong falling-action last episode, and gives the human characters a lot more of the emotion that they're doubtless feeling while Murderbot avoids the awkward squishy elements: I'm glad I watched it. But I enjoyed going back to book elements like the degree to which SecUnits are extended equipment pieces and the use of drones or the feed to mitigate eye contact and other intense moments of social interaction. They wouldn't have made for great TV, I'm sure, but to me they're an integral part of how Murderbot moves through the world.

It's great to realize that I've broken in new comfort reads as an adult, especially those with as many layers as this one. I always feel like I'm noticing some new little detail in Murderbot's tight first-person POV clashing with reality, or some worldbuilding implication that didn't pop until I had the context of later books. The thoughtful construction and strong writing style just keep me coming back.
//
A great reread, just as I'd hoped. Possible RTC, but in short: this is so satisfyingly *focused* across the board. It's great as both an open-ended single entry and as the start of a deeper character arc. Above all, Murderbot's voice is distinctive: I'll read a book about almost anything with the right narrator to carry it.

Remember all those shows you‚Äôve been avoiding, because the dialogue, written by the same two people, sounds like the verbal equivalent of slapstick? Would you like that speech turd repackaged as the protagonist‚Äôs inner monologue, and labelled as "humour"?

I did not. And yet, through my selfish and, at times, reckless avoidance of bad writing, I have provoked the Gods of Desk Drawer Fiction, and faced their wrath. Let me tell you about their punishment.

Murderbot is not what you might expect. When It‚Äôs not regurgitating comedy lines from the shows it binge-watches, Murderbot‚Äôs narration consists of near-constant introspection into Its own emotions, or, alternatively, speculation on what other people might be feeling.

This is a pity, because if I wanted to read a book about a middle-aged, over-emotional divorcee who hits the sauce on most evenings, then tearfully ponders the feelings of her estranged children, I wouldn‚Äôt have picked up a science-fiction book about a cyborg.

Science-fiction is one of the most difficult genres to write. It‚Äôs prohibitively difficult. You need vast scientific and technical knowledge, combined with artistic creativity, and a talent for writing. This is, statistically speaking, an extremely rare combination in humans.

And I cannot beat about the bush ‚Äì for a science-fiction novel, the author does not treat us to many descriptions of science or technology. In fact, you get the impression, she‚Äôs being purposefully vague. Murderbot uses a ‚Äúbig gun.‚Äù It cures Its wounds with a ‚Äúsealant.‚Äù And whether Martha Wells likes it or not, the expression ‚Äúmy organic parts‚Äù sounds like a Victorian Era euphemism for genitals.

To analyse a situation, Murderbot has to watch hours of Its own camera footage in real time. Instead of using any kind of threat modelling, Murderbot judges mission outcomes by how depressed It feels, the migrations of birds in the sky, and shamanic mushrooms.


The book‚Äôs gravest mistake, however, is starting the action after Murderbot‚Äôs self-liberation from its ‚Äúgovernor module.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a reason why Cinderella does not begin with Cinderella already being the princess; parading round the castle in silk taffeta; telling the reader occasional anecdotes of how bad she used to have it with her evil step-mother. This story is static. It doesn‚Äôt lead anywhere. Children would ditch this story, in favour of The Very Hungry Caterpillar, because that, at least, features progression.

A transformation is only appreciated when there‚Äôs little assurance of it; when we walk with our character in darkness, without any certain knowledge that things might change. When we face terror and doubt, and derision; when we recoil in revulsion at Murderbot‚Äôs carnage; when we watch Murderbot kill ‚Äì only then can we begin to appreciate the fact that It stops killing.

If you mean to start in medias res, and you mean business, start in the dark days. Don‚Äôt cheapen your own victory. No prequel can ever absolve the sins of the first book.


All Systems Red makes very little attempt to bring the reader any intellectual satisfaction. The story is simplistic, na√Øve, and rushed to the complete abandonment of character development. The scenes seem cut prematurely. It‚Äôs a summary, more than anything ‚Äì a rushed summary of an idea, with dialogue added on top. The science is non-existent, the fiction is a quandary I lay at the feet of relativity.

I‚Äôm kidding. It‚Äôs bad.
The author uses words like ‚Äúbird-thing.‚Äù

And that is why I recommend reading this book in no other manner, than with Ramblin‚Äô Gamblin‚Äô Man by Bob Seger, playing on full blast. I think it improves the experience by 20%.

Rest assured, the future got an upward trajectory: literally. Corporate dominated planetary missions must be approved by the Company. Every exploratory team will be supplied with a security assistant, for safety.

But in this society, safety's not exactly the top priority.

A tale of mortals and a being so much more than a machine. Free will means quite a lot, whether you're human or bot.

Trigger warnings injury, violence, and death.

Shy, socially awkward Murderbot was not your average killer. No, they were a pessimist who just wanted to find out who they really were. As soon as the relatably snarky introvert spoke, I wanted to (sorry Murderbot) give them a hug.

Murderbot+ real humans = awkward. Even though the bad**s bot tried to fly under the radar, their relationship with her team was anything but mechanical. Trust, feelings, and humanly dealings are hard. However, the relationship of observation and need slowly grew into something unexpectedly friendly.

Emotions are not errors. Action packed, this spacey, character driven story burst with perfectly timed humor. Life like but not quite, this "mindless cyborg's" perspective hit the the vulnerability accompanying free will and finding yourself on the head. A shooting star, Murderbot: All Systems Red completely captivated my attention as it flew by. The first diary installment, Martha Wells's non-human examination of humanity was fascinating.

All systems say read Murderbot: All Systems Red.

2025 update: It's funny to see the escalation in the amount of rereading that happens year after year
____________________________________

2024 update: I get sad or stressed or mad? I read Murderbot.
____________________________________

Re-read 2022 & 2023 Update: All-Time Favorite.

I have nothing else to add other than that Murderbot is the best.
____________________________________

I COULD HAVE BECOME a mass murderer after I hacked my governor module, but then I realized I could access the combined feed of entertainment channels carried on the company satellites. It had been well over 35,000 hours or so since then, with still not much murdering, but probably, I don‚Äôt know, a little under 35,000 hours of movies, serials, books, plays, and music consumed. As a heartless killing machine, I was a terrible failure.

Rating: Absolutely Loved It (potential for all-time favorite rating for sure)

How could I NOT fall in love with Murderbot with an opening like that???

Should I be concerned with how much I relate to a human-robot construct who sees their sole purpose for existence to murder? Probably. Am I really that concerned? NO!

Poor Murderbot just wants to be left alone to consume their various forms of media in peace, and the humans in their charge just keep narrowly escaping death and then trying to do weird and annoying things like TALK to them about FEELINGS. BUT WHY!? I felt like Murderbot and I could be the same person at times: the social anxiety, the extreme introvertedness, the cynical and sarcastic inner monologue. This is the most I have related to a main character since House in the Cerulean Sea. I swear some of Murderbot's lines were things I have expressed to friends at one time or another.

Okay, done gushing, I will try to move to a more cohesive review mind now. Novellas are really hit or miss for me, so I was somewhat apprehensive going into this one. The world building and the characters other than Murderbot are not super well defined, but I didn't find that it took away from the story. I was primarily focused on Murderbot and getting to know them better. I think that if Murderbot isn't a character that you connect with, or someone whose humor you find to your taste, then this won't be that big of a hit with you.

Ultimately the storyline and the setting were somewhat unremarkable, but they were made fun and entertaining by the presence of our friend Murderbot. I found it well-written and really easy to plow through due to my thorough enjoyment of the character. However, if I didn't love Murderbot as much as I do, it would not have been the same experience.

I found the ending really interesting and I am looking forward to see what becomes of Murderbot in the upcoming adventures! I found their interactions with the humans really touching and am interested to see what becomes of the conversation that was begun regarding constructs as life forms with rights and personalities. 
I also really hope that Mensah shows up again because I loved the way that she interacted with Murderbot. I really hope that they are able to work the existing prejudices in the world and come back together as buddies. Fingers crossed!

This isn't so much commentary on the book as it is that I found it interesting that Murderbot never genders themselves throughout the book. The story is told exclusively from first person POV, and they seem to be non-binary, but they are a construct so gender isn't really a thing for them anyway. It's really interesting to read different reviews and see how different people gendered them in their minds. The humans on the mission with them refer to them as "it" which makes me sad, but it seems to be part of that engrained prejudice against constructs that they still retain, even if they are much more progressive than their fellow humans in the galaxy.

Original Review:

As it says in the blurb, Murderbot hacked its governor module‚Äîfor those not mechanically inclined, think of it as a choke collar. While it follows its orders so that it isn't discovered and risk getting scrapped, it has the freedom to ignore commands it doesn't want to carry out or just pretend to carry them out. It doesn't want to talk about its feelings or hang out with the human crew. It wants to spend as much free time as possible watching thousands of hours of entertainment media it downloaded. Introverts everywhere will identify with Murderbot and quite possibly want its weapons complement to keep pesky annoyances at bay.

The novella is told entirely from Murderbot's POV, but it is perceptive enough to gauge others' reactions to it. And the internal dialogue is full of plenty biting humor that I guffawed audibly several times, eliciting curious inquiries from my family.

Being part-organic, Murderbot isn't invincible either. Although the company has built them to be self-repairing, they are disposable to some extent. Murderbot's vulnerability is made obvious to the reader from the outset. But despite this, Murderbot doesn't hesitate to throw itself into danger. Is its programming overriding self-preservation, or does it actually have a smidge of empathy for the humans it's assigned to protect? That's up to the reader to figure out.

Highly enjoyable.
