Jan 2020:
At this point in my life, it's rare for me to re-read a book as there's so much that I haven't read that it makes more sense to journey through those undiscovered worlds. But the day after Christmas I found myself in a hotel room in Maine where my kindle couldn't talk to the wireless network. A new book I'd intended to read apparently hadn't downloaded and thus couldn't update. I decided to re-read a book I had on hand and, considering the circumstances, I opted to hang out with Murderbot. Later on, I managed to find a book in the ransacked remnants of the book section of some OddLots-style store and switched to that. I set Murderbot aside.

And then my dad died on New Year's Eve.

I was on a plane New Year's Day to travel to my parents' house. Just sitting there with nothing to do, I desperately needed a distraction from my grief. And just as Murderbot preferred to hide from humans with its visor opaque on its helmet, I needed the same. So I picked up right where I left off.

It's not that I found comfort in words of wisdom from the author. It's not that this was some big revenge fantasy‚Äîthere was no one to take revenge upon for my father's death. It's that the story was familiar, short, pure escapism, and had a main character that I could relate to: an introvert that just wanted to be left alone, didn't want to hang out making small talk, and certainly didn't want to discuss its feelings.

You can read into that any way you want.

It's been ages since I've read a sci-fi novel. And I have nothing against the genre. Somehow, though, I rarely pick sci-fi books. Time to change it.

All Systems Red has an interesting premise - On a distant planet, a team of scientists is conducting surface tests, shadowed by their Company-supplied ‚Äòdroid ‚Äî a self-aware SecUnit that has hacked its own governor module, and refers to itself as ‚ÄúMurderbot.‚Äù

Despite this name, there's not much mayhem in the book. Actually, Murderbot is mostly interested in binge-watching shows on entertainment feeds. Fates of fictional characters are more important to it than the fates of scientist team she's supposed to protect.

Unfortunately, it seems there's sort of a sabotage and lives are at stakes. Murderbot will have to make few important decisions.

The story is told from the first-person perspective of a Murderbot. It seems people tend to enjoy her snarky narration. Personally, I couldn't connect to her / its voice. There's a serious lack of character and character development. The team of scientists is barely sketched, at times it's difficult to keep track of different characters as most of them have absolutely no personality.


‚ÄúConfession time: I don‚Äôt actually know where we are. We have, or are supposed to have, a complete satellite map of the planet in the survey package. That was how the humans decided where to do their assessments. I hadn‚Äôt looked at the maps yet and I‚Äôd barely looked at the survey package. In my defense, we‚Äôd been here twenty-two planetary days and I hadn‚Äôt had to do anything but stand around watching humans make scans or take samples of dirt, rocks, water, and leaves. The sense of urgency just wasn‚Äôt there. Also, you may have noticed, I don‚Äôt care.


As you see Murderbot doesn't care much about her team and isn't interested in nuances of their behavior. As a result, we don't learn about it. Think of them as chess pieces. Mostly pawns.

Overall, it's an interesting novella but because I couldn't connect to Murderbot's voice, my enjoyment was limited.

Murderbot is a sarcastic, socially awkward joy. I can't remember the last protagonist I read who had such a distinct voice; dry and grumpy but also resolutely loyal and quietly kind. Wells manages to transmit an incredible complexity of emotion below Murderbot's prickly exterior; doggedly protecting its humans and monologuing about free will while all the while reminding us it really just wants to be watching its TV show right now. Murderbot is a love letter to all of us who don't always have the energy, the patience, or, let's face it, the passion for social interaction.

Plot-wise, this novel does an incredible job of packing a compelling, well-paced story into a neat 144 pages. The corporate colonization of the universe through various arms of "The Company" is an interesting, insidious framework that makes teases at a broader world, though Wells does an excellent job of keeping the focus on Murderbot and the Preservation crew. Though the star of the story is unquestionably Murderbot there is a surprisingly broad (and by this I mean 5+) cast of main supporting characters, and to my pleasant surprise I felt like I had a good sense of all of them by the conclusion of the novella. I cannot stress how difficult this is to do in such a short span, especially when the POV spotlight is elsewhere.

For a book that is equally about autonomy and the evils of capitalism as it is the sheer agony of eye contact, All Systems Red manages to be a perfectly charming, breezy read. I've truly never wanted to hug a character more who would NOT appreciate my doing so. I could read a hundred Murderbot novellas and fall in love a little more each time.

Original review:

This review originally appeared over at Booknest.eu!

Copy borrowed from my local library. Support libraries, folks!

While browsing through the rows of books in English in the Swedish library I frequent, I came across Martha Wells‚Äô All Systems Red, a novella whose cover I dimly recalled seeing years before on Tor.com. I looked through my To-Read list and ‚Äì surprise! ‚Äì this one was nowhere near it‚Ä¶as if that would stop me. I grabbed it, stole away Ada Palmer‚Äôs Too Like the Lightning as well, in case someone thought this thin novella too conspicuous. Long live sci-fi!

By the end of the night, I‚Äôd read through the first of these titles with barely any effort.

All Systems Red offers a fun story from the point of view of an anxiety-riddled robot with several biological components and a touch of misanthropy: ‚ÄúI liked the imaginary people on the entertainment feed way more than I liked real ones, but you can‚Äôt have one without the other‚Äù. This SecUnit calls itself Murderbot and seeks to avoid all direct interactions with its human wards, interested only in watching the tv, music and game programmes on entertainment channels. If this isn‚Äôt enough to make the Murderbot relatable, I don‚Äôt know what will.

Stuck on a planet with a band of scientists performing geological studies, our protagonist hopes to avoid any sort of excitement; unfortunately for him, this is a sci-fi novella intent on putting Murderbot on the spot and testing its mettle! A few action scenes are only to be expected ‚Äì and they were well handled and entertaining.

The prose is serviceable ‚Äì not quite excellent, but it doesn‚Äôt need to be. There‚Äôs plenty of great interactions, the dialogue never tends towards the heavily expositional and the personalities of all the scientists, led by team leader Mensah, shined through. Oh, and the humour? Golden: ‚ÄúYes, talk to Murderbot about its feelings. The idea was so painful I dropped to 97 percent efficiency. I‚Äôd rather climb back into Hostile One‚Äôs mouth.‚Äù

In terms of antagonists, the architects behind our protagonist‚Äôs woes don‚Äôt make for anything especially memorable; they‚Äôre rather archetypal, presenting rather the depths to which human greed tends to go when a group of people goes off the deep end. It works well and keeps our SecUnit and his group of scientists on their toes and pushing themselves as hard as they can to survive.

Once embroiled in a crisis, Murderbot is willing to put its life on the line for the band of humans it has been tasked with protecting ‚Äì despite it hacking its governance module. The same module that allows anyone who‚Äôs signed a deal with the Company ‚Äì like the scientists ‚Äì to command Murderbot. By working to save Mensah and the rest of her team from a shadowy enemy, then, Murderbot is exercising its free will ‚Äì and this is at the heart of what‚Äôs examined in Wells‚Äô novel. The question is one of freedom and compassion and examination of the self, and the text goes a long way in showing how Murderbot exercises all three.

My score for All Systems Red is a 4/5. This is a legitimately enjoyable adventure in a science fiction setting with plenty of good zingers and a socially awkward Robocop ‚Äì what‚Äôs not to love?! I‚Äôm looking forward to reading more about Murderbot in the future! I‚Äôll definitely be picking up his story when I‚Äôm next in my local library!

I almost really liked this book.

Right off the bat, it was clear Murderbot's personality was what will keep the reader engaged, and it mostly managed to do that. The first chapter is hilarious, and the depiction of Murderbot as the incarnation of that voice in our head that says: "I wish everyone would die and leave me alone, but I can't deal with that so I'll just watch TV instead" is spot on, and is relatable in a wonderfully morbid way.

Trouble comes on three fronts: one, Murderbot has a story arc that doesn't make sense. Two, everything besides Murderbot is completely uninteresting. Three, the writing is... strange.

The first: Murderbot was a wonderfully intriguing character at the beginning, but that was because it seemed like it truly was a depressed killing machine. Very quickly it turns out that it cares tremendously about human beings and would readily risk its life to save strangers.
Another point is the ending, which comes out of nowhere: 
after telling us for the entire book that it wants nothing other than to be left alone and watch TV, it suddenly decides to become independent and travel to an unknown destination, saying how it wants to be free and not follow anyone.

The second: the story and characters are significantly lacking. The plot is the most generic possible, the characters are (almost) all flat. It partly works because this is how Murderbot sees the world, as it doesn't pay much attention to people. But I, the reader, do care. Many choices and actions make little sense, the antagonists are behind the scenes for the entire book until they appear for five minutes and are quickly dealt with (in a way that doesn't make sense). We are told about the characters' relationship status (a loner with a crush, a lesbian couple, one in a four way marriage, one in a three way marriage, etc), but are told nothing else about their lives. Murderbot claims to not care at all about sex, but that's the only thing it tells us about its coworkers.

The third: the writing style is strange to me (it might be more about me than the book, as I'm not a native english speaker).
The descriptions sometimes fail to take into account things the author knows but the reader doesn't. For example: Murderbot attacks two enemies, describing how it took them by surprise and shot them until they stopped moving. Then it describes where and how much it got shot itself. Then it describes how just before the fight had started, it sent a few miniature drones to crash against the enemies. What's with the strange order of events? It made me imagine how the scene went, then forced me to change it a moment later. Most of the action scenes in the book are weirdly described.
This appears in several other places too, where the author apparently lost track of what the reader knows and doesn't know, and it made for an uncomfortable reading.

One additional point, this time about the genre: the sci-fi elements are severely underutilized and unexplored, which feels like a waste. There is not a single sci-fi element here that you haven't already seen a million times before.

Despite the breakthrough success of Martha Wells' Murderbot Diaries series I had previously no interest or FOMO attraction to looking into it. All Systems Red is a wild ride that expertly balances humor, action, and a profound exploration of identity‚Äîall wrapped up in the experiences of a sarcastic, self-aware murderbot. Seriously, how can you resist that premise?

From the moment I met Murderbot, I was hooked. This character is not just another robot; it‚Äôs a being wrestling with its purpose and autonomy, and let‚Äôs be honest, its binge-watching habits. Wells has created a narrator who is equal parts charming and relatable, making it impossible not to root for it‚Äîeven when it tries to avoid the very humans it‚Äôs meant to protect. If you‚Äôve ever felt like you‚Äôre just trying to navigate life while wanting to curl up on the couch with your favorite show, you‚Äôll see a bit of yourself in Murderbot.

The pacing is spot on, propelling you through the story with a rhythm that keeps you engaged. Just when you think you understand the flow, the action ramps up, pulling you right back in. The world-building is so seamless that you feel like you could step into it and join Murderbot and its crew on their adventures.

What really blew me away is how Wells tackles complex themes about agency and connection while keeping it completely entertaining. This isn‚Äôt just a sci-fi adventure; it‚Äôs a thought-provoking journey that challenges you to think about what it means to be truly alive.

This novella is a perfect blend of humor and heart, leaving you with a smile and a sense of connection. It‚Äôs a quick read that not only entertains but also resonates, reminding us that even in a world filled with technology, the search for identity and belonging is timeless.

An exciting start to a series of primarily novellas, I‚Äôm intrigued to see where it‚Äôs headed next.

Wells sets the scene and explains not only the world but our protagonist very quickly. There‚Äôs action, violence, and danger from the beginning, and we‚Äôre left to piece everything together on the fly. This is done so well that I was fully on board much sooner than usual for a sci-fi novel. There are no hurdles or barriers to entry here; Murderbot is upfront about everything you could want and many things you don‚Äôt.

Murderbot perfectly embodies every anxious, cynical, socially awkward person. I love so much about Murderbot, and it was easy to relate to this genderless, self-aware, security android. The melodramatic, cynical, sarcastic inner monologue. The social anxiety and lack of social awareness. The voracious appetite for media. The conflicting desire and fear of being treated as more than a SecUnit. The contempt for human stupidity. It‚Äôs all gold. And while it‚Äôs a bit much in this first book, I have high hopes it‚Äôs leading somewhere interesting.

Wells plants a lot of seeds here. It‚Äôs hard to see in what direction the series will lead, which is awfully refreshing, and I may be new to her writing, but I have a lot of faith in her ability to nurture these seeds into something extraordinary in future instalments.

All Systems Red is the first book in Martha Wells' Murderbot Diaries series and it was a brilliant introduction. Set in a universe where space travel is a regular occurrence and scientific expeditions to far flung planets are sold to the lowest bidder its fairly common for things to go wrong but on their latest mission things are about to get very difficult for our narrator, the part organic / part robot Muderbot.

All intergalactic expeditions must take along a company supplied security unit, ostensibly to protect the humans but equally used to report back any interesting scientific findings. Murderbot is the SecUnit for a team of scientists, one of two groups currently working on a previously unexplored planet. Well aware of their previous failures Murderbot can't afford to make any mistakes on this latest mission, they just need to keep their head down, get the job done and then they'll be free to spend all their time watching the entertainment feed. After a series of strange equipment malfunctions they end up completely losing contact with the other group on planet, a sure sign that something isn't right. Murderbot has to do whatever it takes to keep the humans alive but that may be easier said than done considering they have no idea who the enemy is.

This was a really fun novella to read, Murderbot is such an interesting character with a snarky sense of humour and a definite dislike of having to interact with the people they're supposed to protect. All Systems Red may be a novella but Martha Wells packs a lot in, the combination of humour and action makes this a very quick and easy read and it definitely left me wanting to see more of Murderbot and the rest of the crew.

All Systems Red is a great little sci-fi novella! I had a lot of fun with this. We follow Murderbot- a biological construct who is part robot, part cloned biological material- who has overwritten their control programs. They are serving as a security bot to a group of human researchers on a dangerous planet when things begin to go wrong.

This is short-form fiction which not everyone likes, but I think Murderbot is a great character and the world development is interesting. I'm definitely left with questions at the end of the story, but I imagine some of those answers will come later in the series.

While there is no deep dive into anything, there is some consideration of what makes someone a person and the morality of controlling sentient created beings. This was enjoyable and a very quick read. I will be reading on in the series.

Martha Wells is one of my favorite authors, so I don't know why it took me so long to read this series. Possibly it's because I didn't immediately buy the hardcover edition; I may or may not have mentioned that my e-reader puts me to sleep, so I'm reluctant to use it for anything but going over my own manuscripts. I really don't know what I was thinking.

It's brilliant, of course. The voice of the narrator, Murderbot, is beautifully strong and conveys the character's personality perfectly. I was thinking about how relatively scanty the descriptions of this society are, but that makes sense because of that strong narrative voice. Everything we know is filtered through Murderbot's experience, and calling the series a diary drives home the fact that people don't spend a lot of time thinking or writing about stuff everyone knows. There's no section laying out the details of the company (I love that it's lower-case company) and yet I have a very clear idea of what it does and what it's like.

I already knew, because I have read all of Wells's novels, that she is excellent at conveying character, and the research team of humans comes across as vividly unique in a way a SecUnit would see them. We don't get to know all of them, but the few Murderbot interacts with more deeply are charming or irritating or na√Øve, enough that I worried for their safety.

And Murderbot. I was tempted, in the first maybe half of the novella, to ascribe its personality changes to "becoming human." But of course that's not what's going on. Murderbot has seen humans, both its clients and the ones on the many many shows it watches, and for all its growing desire to protect them, it has no desire to become one. It might be better to say that Murderbot is becoming a person, an individual with needs and desires, and I loved seeing it cope with those developing emotions. (I absolutely love every time it says it has to stop to have an emotion. I don't remember if it says that specifically in this book, but it comes up enough that it gets me every time.)

Dr. Mensah is a remarkable character whose interactions with Murderbot are something else I love. Though because of that, the ending caught me off-guard: 
Mensah buys Murderbot outright, intending to give it freedom in her world, and I was sort of excited by the possibility. So I missed that Mensah, in telling Murderbot she would be its guardian (not much different from owner), didn't say that this was only until Murderbot acclimated to freedom. So Murderbot fleeing was a surprise, and yet clearly the only solution.

When I finally came to my senses and bought all four books, I decided to read them back to back because, you know, why waste any more time? This turned out not to work, but I did read them over the course of two days. So I have more reviews to write. It also means I know they just keep getting better.

'All Systems Red' was such an amazing, fun book. I love Murderbot so much. There's such a relatable humour to it, and it's so loveable. I listened to this book as an audiobook, and although I usually prefer reading, it was great to listen to. It's the perfect novella in my eyes.

I'm going to keep this review relatively short because I wasn't able to make notes. Murderbot is a security robot hired to look after a team of scientists as they survey a planet. It's hacked its governor module and so is technically free to do as it likes, which mostly consists of watching a lot of TV. When the team realise that their planetary data is hijacked to hide information about dangerous wildlife they need to figure out who's responsible, and why.


All they had was Murderbot, who just wanted everyone to shut up and leave it alone so it could watch the entertainment feed all day.



The highlight of this book is Murderbot itself. It has such a fantastic narrative voice, and that's coming from someone who usually prefers third-person narratives. There's an amazing sense of humour to it that's both dry and relatable. Murderbot doesn't like talking to people. It's incredibly awkward. I love a socially anxious robot. At one point it's asked if it's okay and it gets up to stand in the corner of the room in embarrassment. I love it.


Yes, talk to Murderbot about its feelings. The idea was so painful I dropped to 97 percent efficiency.


I also love that Murderbot is a sentient and empathetic character without needing to be human. There's an awareness that it's a different type of individual, that it doesn't necessarily want what humans want. It seems like that's going to be explored in the next novel which I'm excited about.


It‚Äôs wrong to think of a construct as half bot, half human. It makes it sound like the halves are discrete, like the bot half should want to obey orders and do its job and the human half should want to protect itself and get the hell out of here. As opposed to the reality, which was that I was one whole confused entity, with no idea what I wanted to do.


Also! Although the background cast isn't hugely developed, likely because Murderbot doesn't care too much about human information, they are amazingly diverse. You've got a cast full of people of colour, a W/W relationship and causal mentions to polyamory. I always love a sci-fi setting where bigotry doesn't seem to be an important factor.


You may have noticed that when I do manage to care, I‚Äôm a pessimist.


I'm looking forward to the next in the series because it'd be great to see how Murderbot further develops, as well as get more information surrounding worldbuilding through its eyes.

It hacked its governor control, so it has a free will and it chooses to spend its free time reading books and watch tv serials. Has there ever been more relatable bot? Murderbot is cranky, pessimistic and it has the whole "leave-me-alone-you-weird-humans-I-want-to-watch-shows-in-peace" attitude. It doesn't have any gender or sex-related organs, it clarifies it in next for the reader. I love the feeling like it was telling me the story. Its pov was hilarious to read.
I love Murderbot, don't fight me on it.

The plot has mystery elements, action and suspense. The tech side of the setting was interesting. I can't wait to see more of the world and my beloved Murderbot in next installments.
I laughed so much on Murderbot's constant jabs at the company and what a cheap asshats they are, as big corporations always are.

I love the supporting cast of characters. It's a bunch of diverse individuals, many people of color, at least two of them are confirmed to be in polyamorous relationship. It's normalized in the world the story takes place in. The leader of the research team is Dr Mensah, woman of color; she's such a capable leader, she's smart and caring. I hope we'll get to see her in the next installments. The rest of the crew are Ratthi, Pin-Lee, Arada, Gurathin, Volescu and Bharadwaj. The dynamic between the team and Murderbot was so well developed, I love the dynamics!

When I read novellas, I often want them to be a full-length novels. While I don't mind a full novel about Murderbot (@ Martha Wells, pretty please!), All Systems Red works perfectly as a novella, I wouldn't change a thing about it. And that last sentence of the book ended me, no kidding.

I highly recommend to read it!
I can't wait to read the sequel!!!

UPDATE: I have now read this book twice and listened to the audiobook once as well, and after three goes through I can safely say that this is a fantastic book. I still agree with everything from my review - despite thinking slightly more of the story now, so I will not be changing or updating it and the review still reflects my thoughts and opinion after just one read.
_____________

I feel rather conflicted about All Systems Red. It had a lot of potential, and I certainly enjoyed it, but I felt it also missed the mark slightly in places.

Spoiler-free synopsis:
A research team has landed on a not-yet-inhabited planet to survey and collect data on soil composition and mineral deposits.
With the team is a SecUnit; a sentient, half biotic/half organic hybrid bodyguard. These units are standard issue and it is through the eyes of this SecUnit, who refers to itself as Murderbot, that the story is told.
When another survey teams communications drop out and portions of the digital maps they were given start to go missing, Murderbots's research team realises that something is very wrong and that there may be a conspiracy surrounding the planet and possibly corruption in the political systems that put them there.

It seemed to me that this could have been a decent short story, or a great novel of a longer length. As it was, it hung somewhere in the middle.
This is not necessarily a bad thing, but there were elements of the story that I thought we could have had less of, and other elements that I wish we had seen more of.
I guess I will find out if book 2, 'Artificial Condition', contains more of the latter. I hope so.

The combination of story and perspective was very interesting. So much of what was going on was filtered through the lense of our sentient SecUnit.
Her feelings, attitude, prejudices, technological abilities, background, origin and her past experiences all lead to a very cohesive and well realised view point, which is rare in my experience with books that try to do similar. This is an incredibly unique protagonist that despite who they are, will be very relatable to many.

I wish the human characters had been given a bit more page time, or at least had been made more separable to each other.
I found myself regularly getting confused between who is who and which ones played which role in the team.
Although, thinking about it now, I suppose that this helped us gain more of a footing as an outsider. Hiding behind the opaque face mask, full body armour, pretending not to care about anything but the job at hand.

As for how the story developed I thought the pacing was a bit staggered or clunky. There was a lot of talking and making plans - which is fine, but then suddenly the action and consequences had seemingly happened within another page or two! And due to the nature of said actions (keeping it spoiler-free) we rarely saw the aftermath either.
It made sense, but it could be a bit jarring and I couldn't help but wish we had seen a bit more of that stuff.

As for the last few chapters and the conclusion of the story, I REALLY enjoyed it.
It was wrapped up really well, and it left me wanting to start the next book straight away, despite my somewhat mixed feelings on the book as a whole.

I can completely see why this book/series is so popular, but I could also understand if this book wasn't for you.
If you have read and enjoyed either the Imperial Radch series by Ann Leckie,'Excession' by Iain M. Banks or 'Dogs of War' by Adrian Tchaikovsky then I think this book would be for you. Likewise if you enjoy(ed) All Systems Red then I would recommend checking these others out as well.

3.5 stars, rounded up for potential.

________________

Thank you for reading my review!

As I said before, I will definitely be reading the other books in the series at some point. So keep your eyes peeled for those coming in the near future.

Up next for though, for sci-fi, it's going to be Surface Detail by Iain M. Banks.
And as for fantasy it's going to be Elantris by Brandon Sanderson.
Two books that I've been looking forward to a lot, by two of my favourite authors!

Thanks again. Stay safe and keeping reading!

The best straight SF I've read so far in 2017: All Systems Red is a longish novella/shortish book with an engagingly snarky protagonist, humor, mystery, excitement, interesting characters and enough plot twists that I devoured it even more than I normally devour books. Once again Martha Wells has created a completely believable non-human protagonist and I loved it (shout out also to the terrific samurai-esque cover art created by Jaime Jones - cover illustrators don't always get the kudos they deserve from readers.)

Red really delivers in the main character of Murderbot (the book is first person from Murderbot's POV.) Murderbot is physically an organic-techological synthesis and the narration subtly reflects that synthesis; the character growth is beautifully done. And yes, I like typing 'Murderbot.'

I also think 'Murderbot' would be a hellagood name for a cat.

This is the second book I've read fairly recently that follows an AI character, the other being Becky Chambers' A Closed and Common Orbit. There's more meat to Chambers' (longer) book but I enjoyed Wells' Murderbot more as a completely other-than-human intelligence (Chambers' AI character is more about an AI becoming human).

In All Systems Red Murderbot is growing its experience as its unique self and adding to that personality rather than learning how to be human, a fascinating perspective. Murderbot feels like a realistic non-human entity.

Although I got my copy from the library, my love for Wells' writing is compelling me to pop for the hard copy and I'm already slavering for Murderbot Diaries #2.

I really enjoyed this novella which introduced the fantastic Murderbot character. The premise is that in the future (200 years? I don't think it is ever fully specified), corporations rule the galaxy (or an arm of it, also not clearly stated) and as they pillage and terraform various planets, moons, and asteroids, they employ SecUnits (potent, lethal military android used for, well, murder by corporate unities in the story) rather than private security to protect their interests. This is particularly the case in a zone called the Corporate Rim. Our protagonist has removed the governor which basically gives it free will and we are inside its head listening as it "wakes up". It learns about human behavior by watching soap operas obsessively, sometimes providing an excellent comic background.
Our hero makes friends with Dr Mensah from an ecological mission, and this character plays an important role in subsequent stories as one of Murderbot's best friends.
What makes the story so entertaining is that (1) Murderbot has a hilarious and deprecating sense of humor, (2) the story has a great murder mystery at the center of it, and (3) the powers of Murderbot to multi-process, hook into nearly any tech around it, and get healed after catastrophic injuries all makes for fun reading.
So, for light and highly entertaining soft science fiction, All Systems Red is a great novella.

Unlike millions of other SecUnits, this one is complicated, smart and individualistic - things that Units aren't supposed to be. As the situation on the planet becomes dangerous and the SecUnit shows himself to be trustworthy, his clients grow attached to him. And although he's programmed to be impersonal, he grows fond of them in a distant, confused way.

The best part of this book is seeing how the SecUnit fights against emotions he doesn't understand and doesn't want to understand. Although I enjoyed the skulduggery elements too (I have thus far neglected to mention the major storyline involving sabotage, murder and bribery), it was the brilliantly written SecUnit's struggle with his unnatural feelings of humanity that pushed this book from good to great and nearly perfect. I just wish it had been longer and shared more of SecUnit's background.

Rating 4 out of 5 | B+ Sardonic, Robots with a personality.

Synopsis

In a distant world, a group of planetary explorers are engaged in the survey of the land which has been recently uncovered. This group of novice surveyors/ scientists from a group known as PreservationAux had bought a commission from the corporation to scope out the planet‚Äôs resources. Once the survey was completed, if the effort was worth the profit they would get a larger share.

Assisting and guarding them in this mission is the security unit, which refers to itself as the Murderbot. Part and parcel of the contract from the company, along with the habitats, hub systems, hoppers, and everything necessary to sustain life on the unknown planet.

The SecUnit which calls itself Murderbot, was involved in a previous accident, where faulty implants from the company had malfunctioned; resulting in it slaughtering every person in the vicinity. While a terrible legal & PR nightmare, the Secunit was far too valuable to be scrapped, and so the company rebooted it, loaded new programs, as well as new governor modules the main function of which was to make sure that the Murderbot was never capable of inflicting harm on the humans that were its charges.

Unknown to the company, the survey group or anyone for that matter, this particular SecUnit had managed to hack into its governor module, giving it a level of independence. More importantly, no longer leaving it tethered with the failsafe protocols to protect the humans. What does our murderbot do with this new found freedom? Does it go about a second round of manslaughter? Or does it run away into the wide cosmos to unfettered freedom?

Neither, it downloads several terabytes worth of entertainment programs, binge watching it during its idle time, in speeds incomprehensive to mere human minds. For the most part it is content to perform its assigned job, protect the humans, watch its serials and make sure to act like an obedient automaton so as not to draw unneeded attention to its unique condition.

Which is proving to be more difficult than it thought, as the humans which are under its protection are being subject to dangerous situations on a constant basis. Now Murderbot has to make a decision; does it continue to feign ignorance, leaving the humans to their fate; Or help them live, thereby exposing his condition to scrutiny and possible termination?


Thoughts

Murderbot has quite a personality; even when it might not come across as likable/ comprehensive to others, it sticks to its own nature and makes decisions based on a complex mix of indifference and neutral altruism.

Murderbot, contrary to what it calls itself, doesn‚Äôt hold any animosity to humans. If you want to categorize its feelings, it would be something like being ‚ÄòLawful Neutral‚Äô. It takes care of the humans because they are its responsibility. But, technically, since it has hacked the Governor module, it has no compulsion to carry out said duty. It does regardless, because it has a sense of responsibility.

Murderbot is pretty indifferent to humans, and doesn‚Äôt want to get close to them, or interact with them to any degree. This group from PreservationAux, largely leave him to his own devices, and unlike other humans don‚Äôt exploit him, or treat him like a slave. They give him space, and a modicum of respect. This makes them appreciable to the murderbot. And while it doesn‚Äôt care what happens to them, because it likes how they treat it, Murderbot does everything in their power to make sure they stay alive.

Original Review 6/24/18:

Yes, talk to Murderbot about it's feelings. The idea was so painful I dropped to 97 percent efficiency.

I'm not much of a sci-fi gal, since the jargon and overall concepts usually confuse me. I also am just not really into futuristic stories or stories set in space, since I can't conceptualize a lot of whats going on. But after having some success with the Illuminae Files series, I'm intrigued by the genre. I picked up All Systems Red because it's less than 150 pages and I've seen some pretty good reviews of it, so I figured if I should start with sci-fi anywhere, it should be here.

Overall, I liked this book. Murderbot is hilarious and honestly one of the most relatable characters I've come across. The trope of a self-aware AI with a sense of humor is always so funny and appealing to me, and I loved reading from its point-of-view. I think it's pretty awesome when an author can make a robot relatable.

I, for some reason, got a very femme vibe from Murderbot, even though it has no gender. I've never gotten a female impression from any AI I've ever read, but there's something about this antisocial queen that tugged on my heartstrings. Maybe I just saw a bit too much of myself in Murderbot. I think one of the funniest parts of the book is when Dr. Mensah asked if Murderbot would like to spend time with the crew, and Murderbot--who cannot control its facial expressions readily--gives a look of absolute horror at the prospect of spending time with people. Like, bitch, me too. Talking to people is hard. Murderbot also stands in the corner of the room facing the wall when talking in group settings and I just wish that behavior was acceptable for me, because same.

The writing is a little choppy and not very pretty, but I've never read anything else by Martha Wells, so I'm not sure if this was a tactic to make it truly seem like a robot was telling us the story or if she's just a writer who doesn't care about whether her words sound nice. I didn't hate it, but sometimes the choppy wording and sentences could be a tad awkward and I would have to reread them. But the writing lent itself to letting the story move fast, which I always like.

What flopped in this book for me was the plot and the ending. The last two chapters were confusing and vague, and I couldn't tell you what the GrayCris group was trying to accomplish and why Murderbot's group had anything to do with it. It was never explained, and I found the fact that Murderbot was unconcious for a majority of the action scenes to be a tad lazy on the author's part. The last chapter was also weird, I don't understand quite what happened since it seemed like everything important had been completely missed by Murderbot and no one bothered to explain it to them. The last few pages seemed out of character for Murderbot as well, and I have no idea why it ended that way or where it will take us in the future.

I know this is a series with 3 more books, so I'm guessing we'll learn a lot more about that planet they were on, their mission, the GrayCris group, and why everything happened the way it did. But it seems kind of silly to me to have a 150 page book were things sort of happened and but never got explained. I wanted to love this story, because I really love Murderbot, but nothing seemed to make much sense by the end.

I will definitely continue the series since these books are so short and I want more of Murderbot's hilarious narration. I just hope that this story doesn't go in a completely random direction like the ending seemed to promise. I need answers, and I also need more of the human characters introduced in order to truly care for this story. If the next book is solely about Murderbot's journey and we never see those people again or get any answers I'll be pretty pissed. 150 pages just wasn't enough time to articulate an effective plot, at least for this author.

This was my first experience with Martha Wells and her science fiction Murderbot series. It has an interesting premise, to say the least. The story is told from the point of view from a robot, referred to as security unit. Tis unit has managed to override its governor installed device that directs and controls its actions, which has enabled it to develop a sense of independence and free agency. It has named itself Murderbot, hates being around humans, but yet has a voracious appetite for watching serial television shows.

In this first novella in the series, ‚ÄúAll Systems Red,‚Äù Murderbot is part of a corporate (called ‚ÄúThe Company) financed scientific expedition on an alien planet. His role is protecting the research scientists because safety isn‚Äôt always as good as it could be in uncharted space. Unfortunately. Murderbot discovers information about the local fauna is missing from their survey information, as well as sections missing from their local area mappings. Then things get worse when they lose contact with the other expedition group on the other side of the planet. It‚Äôs up to Murderbot and his team of scientists to figure out what is happening before it‚Äôs too late.

There was a lot of buzz for this series, both in favor and against it for various reasons. After finishing the first novella, I can see support for both sides.

It is a unique approach that is delivered for the most part in an interesting and refreshing style. I thought about how hard it must be to write in first-person and pull off such a challenging view.

I am sure that there will be many who disagree with my assessment, but it‚Äôs my view and I am sticking with it.

My other critique is one that many have already hit upon, and it is a passionate criticism from many when I looked at various Goodreads and Amazon reviews. It‚Äôs nothing new, but I am rather surprised by the pricing for these Murderbot novellas. Hardcover/softcover copies run about $12 or $13 while Kindle/electronic versions run around $11. They are novellas, not midsize or lengthy novels ‚Äì around 150 pages in length ‚Äì which makes the pricing seem cost prohibitive. It is a unique approach that is delivered for the most part in an interesting and refreshing style. I thought about how hard it must be to write in first-person and pull off such a challenging view.

They are novellas, not midsize or lengthy novels ‚Äì around 150 pages in length ‚Äì which makes the pricing seem cost prohibitive. Since this is already a sore point for many people, I will refrain from further comments.

Overall, this was an interesting read that provided hope for further development and potential in future books. Definitely worth reading. However, on a personal level, I am not sure it lives up fully to the accolades it has received. Wells brings a unique voice told through a dark and distinctive android character. One that is her own and she delivers it in a style that is both clinical and exploratory of human emotions and desires. Overall, I liked it enough to give the second novella a read. However, I will be checking it out from my local library, rather than paying the current price. That‚Äôs where I am at for now. We‚Äôll see how it progresses before I commit to anything more‚Ä¶

Okay, first, "Murderbot" is definitely a misleading sobriquet. The protagonist may apply that nickname to itself, but ironically. I mention this because the title was kind of a turn-off for me, but this whole "murderous android" thing is very much overblown.

All Systems Red, the first installment in Martha Wells' The Murderbot Diaries and winner of the 2018 Hugo, Locus, and Nebula Awards, is a heck of a lot of fun. This is a novella, so the premise is pretty simple - a rogue android has to help keep the humans who have contracted it for security alive during a planetary survey mission. Naturally, Wells inserts a few wrinkles along the way that point to something larger and more nefarious. A murderbot has to earn its pay, after all.

What separates All Systems Red from the pack of droid hero science fiction is the character of Murderbot itself. Murderbot has hacked the governor module that controls and dictates its behavior, making it a free agent, if not for the fact that it has to hide this tidbit of information from its human employers. Despite being fully self-aware and keenly intelligent, Murderbot is still listed as inventory in the Company that contracts it out for security services, so certain ruses must be maintained if Murderbot doesn't want to see itself reformatted and re-enslaved to its corporate masters.

Murderbot may not be human, although it does have some fleshy components, but it is most decidedly a person. Wells gives enough depth to Murderbot to make it sympathetic, relying on the android's personality and issues of human bias and notions of superiority in our historical dealings with artificial intelligences to give us a healthy degree of perspective on where exactly Murderbot is coming from.

And where Murderbot is coming from is decidedly simple - it hates humans and just wants to be left alone to watch its favorite downloaded television shows. Never before have I found an artificial intelligence to be so utterly relatable! While I can fully sympathize with Murderbot's ambitions, it's pretty damn hilarious listening to its encounters with its new human crew and their attempts to humanize a wryly grumpy killing machine, and how Murderbot responds to such showings of support and empathy. The scientific team it is charged with protecting is nicely drama free, but Wells manages to wring a good bit of emotive action out of how Murderbot and its crew respond to each other. Wells doesn't get deeply philosophical about the nature of life, intelligence, and free will, but she does raise a few poignant issues worth thinking about over the course of this short book.

Experiencing All Systems Red in audiobook format, though, leaves me slightly conflicted. It took me a while to warm to Kevin R. Free's narration, and while his reading here is serviceable I wish it were more engaging. Murderbot actually has feelings - it gets angry, its gets sarcastic, and it knows when it needs to be emotionally manipulative to draw out desired responses from the humans around it. Free's reading is dry and largely monotone; this makes for a dull listen despite Murderbot being anything but a dull character. I wish Free would have taken a livelier approach to the material, but I did eventually come around to his style - not enough to rave about his vocal showmanship, but enough that I'm still interested in pursuing this series in audio rather than switching over to print (at least for book two).

Although the narration didn't do the story justice, the character of Murderbot is most definitely one worth paying attention to and has me eager to sink straight into Artificial Condition next. I can't wait to see what further hijinks my new favorite anti-social killing machine gets up to!

A Snickers candy-bar has three things going for it: it‚Äôs sweet, it‚Äôs crunchy, and it‚Äôs only 1.86 oz. Cause you know that saying, too much of a good thing is a bad thing? With Snickers, it‚Äôs more like too much of a bad thing is, uh, still a bad thing‚Ä¶ but in small quantities, eh, not so bad, takes the edge off at least.

That more or less summarizes how I feel about these murder-bot diaries: the protagonist (self-named ‚ÄúMurderbot‚Äù) is a bit crunchy and a bit sweet, and it‚Äôs good that these are novellas and not full length novels. Just like a Snickers bar, they‚Äôre real easy to consume, and I don‚Äôt want to undervalue that. Reading each in one sitting is a great way to spend the afternoon.

And to give more substantive praise, probably the best part of these novellas is the way they extend corporate dystopia into the realm of space exploration. The Murderbot begins its life as a ‚ÄúSecBot,‚Äù a security/protection android that its company REQUIRES for exploration/survey groups to qualify for insurance (and also lets the company steal data‚Ä¶). While corporate dystopia is nothing new to sci-fi, this more intimate boots-on-the-ground perspective feels fresh within the context of space exploration.

However, these are otherwise absolute junk food. These are books heavily featuring robots and AI and hacking, written by someone who KNOWS ABSOLUTELY NOTHING ABOUT ANY OF THAT. You know that amazingly absurd 1995 film, Hackers? That‚Äôs about the level of accuracy of hacking/robotics/AI in this book.

In writing, we have this phrase ‚Äúwrite what you know.‚Äù I hate that phrase. I despise it utterly. Please, writers, don‚Äôt restrict yourself to ‚Äúwhat you know.‚Äù Please use your empathy to write from perspectives not your own. Please depict worlds beyond what we currently know.

But do your research. I‚Äôm not asking for a textbook on encryption or cyber-sec. But if you‚Äôve written a quarter of a million words in which ‚Äúhacking‚Äù is the primary method by which your protagonist resolves conflicts and you never use basic terminology like ‚Äúfirewall‚Äù or ‚Äúencryption‚Äù (much less sophisticated jargon like ‚Äúsanitizing input‚Äù or ‚Äúair-gap‚Äù) then your story is probably bullshit, isn‚Äôt it?

In that respect, I find it a bit disturbing that people nominated and then awarded these books for not just one Hugo but FOUR. MORE ACTUALLY! They wanted to give MORE! AND two Nebulas. That's like giving the story equivalent of a MCDONALD‚ÄôS the ‚Äúbest restaurant award.‚Äù For better or worse, the field of science fiction literature is now dominated by people who have only the most tenuous grasp of actual science, technology, mathematics, and philosophy.

Also, as a final and related note, each of these books is like $20. I‚Äôm sorry but what? You‚Äôre charging steak-dinner prices for a candy bar. Ironic, considering this is a book set against a backdrop of corporate greed.

With hindsight, this first story is simple and has some intrigue. It could easily have faded into nothing and then we wouldn't have had all of the cool follow-up adventures that Murderbot goes on, so I'm glad it got famous.
Initially I gave this a 4-star but on the reread I'm dropping it to a 3.5.

Murderbot Diaries: 4/5

‚ÄúIn the creche, our moms always said that fear was an artificial condition. It's imposed from the outside‚Ä¶You should do the things you're afraid of‚Äù.

Murderbot is one of those stories that holds a special place in the hearts of those who read it. I'd wager that those that don't normally pick up Sci-Fi would find a nook to keep their experience with Murderbot. The Sci-Fi here is just a catalyst that allows for the real story to shine. A study on human existence and emotions through the lens of an anthropomorphic artificial construct, that all of a sudden has free will. The existential dread that Murderbot encounters and the way it chooses to cope with the situations is like many of us; Escapism through art, i.e. movies, shows, reading.

Me being me and catching up on all the books i've missed, I was able to binge these four back-to-back. It lent itself to being able to be immersed in the story. The writing was so structurally sound it's a no brainer why Martha Wells has been nominated for and won so many awards. A master of the craft if you will. And even though Murderbot is at its core about a melancholy robot struggling with deep human emotions, Wells weaves in comedy and does it well. It's inherently wholesome.

Wells is able to propel the story forward without it feeling rushed, forced, or predictable. When an author is able to deliver on that it makes the reading experience flow smoothly. Everything that Murderbot accomplishes feels earned. His wins feel like our wins. His emotional growth feels like our growth. I also just have to smirk about the fact that as Murderbot grows more mature, so does his choice of words. LOL. It's just hilarious to have Murderbot just nonchalantly throw out an F bomb. Love it.

Murderbot is a great way to explore heavy themes in a cheeky package. And it has become a nice comfy read for me.

‚ÄúI was having an emotion, and I hate that‚Äù.


All Systems Red: 3.5/5

All Systems Red was a solid introduction to our new friend, Murderbot. We understand the basic groundwork for his goals and his reasons for his actions. This novella was a nice window into the universe we‚Äôre in, I just wanted a little more from it. It felt like this first entry could have been shorter and set the same hooks into readers.

Artificial Condition: 4/5

Artificial Condition gave us a broader scope of the universe and a deeper dive into Murderbot, which I enjoyed. We get to see Murderbot interact at length with another AI, also known as ART. This is a part of the story that was the cherry on top. In the environment between Murderbot and ART, Murderbot is playing the role of human and it makes for awesome scenes (Older sibling like). We get to experience Murderbot's first ‚Äúfriend‚Äù. Artificial Condition is also where we get to dive deeper into Murderbot‚Äôs history and learn a little about why he is the way he is. As Murderbot gets to spend more time independently and not as a robot-for-hire we get to see his personality at the forefront of the narrative.

Rogue Protocol:4.5/5

Rogue Protocol steps it up with everything that made the last two entries great. Not only does the action get turned up to 11 but so do the existential situations Murderbot gets put into. He meets Abene and her ‚Äúpet‚Äù robot Miki. He has to dissect the relationship between the two and desperately tries to understand the bond the two have. Can Murderbot call a human a friend? Is he more human than he realizes? Murderbot vs some combat robots? HELL YEAH!

Exit Strategy: 4/5

In Exit Strategy, Murderbot's emotional growth throughout the first three stories coalesces here when he finally faces what he's been pondering alone. Can he have human friends? Is Murderbot‚Äôs most recent actions the result of him wanting to help his new friends? He even posits this with him questioning if he is still hardwired to help humans or is this now his own choice. Does he care enough about Mensa to freely make the decision to help her? Now with the ability to be alone without his existence being in trouble, Murderbot can really dive deep into free will and come up with his own answer‚Ä¶ or maybe just watch some serials like we all probably do *Haha*

‚ÄúYoung humans can be impulsive. The trick is keeping them around long enough to become old humans‚Äù.

The Good
‚Äì Sharp storytelling
‚Äì Fun and entertaining
‚Äì Incredibly likeable main character
‚Äì Quick and easy to read

The Bad
‚Äì A few critically weak points in prose
‚Äì Hard to keep track of secondary characters at times

Legit, Murderbot charmed its way into my heart by the end of the first paragraph.

Story
Quick, straightforward and enjoyable.

After Murderbot‚Äîa security construct who's hacked itself into autonomy‚Äîrescues a member of the survey team under its protection from a dangerous creature not registered on the planet's flora and fauna list, the group realizes something is wrong. They're unsure if the missing details in their information are an attempt at sabotage or a genuine error on the company's part, who are known for cutting corners and supplying cheap equipment.

However, the necessary actions it takes to save Dr. Volescu and Dr. Bharadwaj reveal it's more human than the team believed: for one, the security bots have a human face. A "generic" one, but something human-looking all the same. If Murderbot's autonomy is discovered by the company, they will terminate it and scrap it for parts.

Murderbot does not want to be terminated and scrapped for parts. Murderbot wants to watch media programs.

Wells has combined a lovely mixture of fun, conversational storytelling with some brutal moments and questions about humanness. All Systems Red is entertaining and compulsively readable without feeling overwhelming. There were a couple parts that I thought could be tightened further or where Wells could dig in a little more. But overall it's a very, very good novella. There's almost always something to look forward to if there isn't anything already something interesting and enjoyable on the page.

Characters
Murderbot is a star. Murderbot makes All Systems Red a star.

Murderbot is both someone other and unfamiliar‚Äîhow it functions, what it's capable of, its position in the universe‚Äîand something painfully human and relatable. It's lazy. It's socially awkward. It really, really wants to watch some TV. In this way, Murderbot is both distinctly human and distinctly not, and it is a charming and wonderful narrator.

Something I loved about Murderbot from a world-building angle is how Wells balanced Murderbot's murder abilities with its comparative fragility. Is Murderbot terrifying compared to squishy humans? Absolutely. Can Murderbot take a frankly horrifying amount of damage while still remaining functional? Oh, yeah. But at the end of the day, it's still one security android comprised of cheap parts up against other security android comprised of cheap parts. To quote: This is how we fight: throw ourselves at each other and see whose parts give out first.

Murderbot is in charge of the safety of eight humans, who are somewhat frustrating to keep track of mentally. This is due in part to the restraints of the novella, and in part to what the story is trying to achieve. We need to care about these humans at least a little bit, but it doesn't make sense to flesh them out too deeply when there isn't room for in the narrative. Wells has come up with a delightful explanation for this in the book, but it doesn't change the fact that outside of Dr. Mensah and Dr. Gurathin, the cast is rather interchangeable.

Writing Style
Told in first person, something tense, Wells conveys All Systems Red in a conversational, accessible and wry style.

Despite this, there are some occasional weak points an established author should've eliminated from their prose by now‚Äînamely a surprising number of had hads.

Themes and Representation
Touches on the ethics and morality of ownership of self-aware beings.

There are minimal details about them, but the supporting cast was culturally diverse and there was at least one LGBT+ relationship among them. Polyamorous relationships and marriages are common.

Recommended For...
Those who want a short, well-rounded story with an immensely delightful main character.

[Relisten completed 7/2/2020 - This is one of the small collection of audiobooks in my Audible library that I listen to repeatedly. If I still had an Audible membership, I'd probably consider spending credits on the other works in the series. I do have paper copies now, though, so I'm just waiting for my current reading game to give me an opportunity to read Artificial Condition.]

Murderbot is a SecUnit that hacked its own governor module a while back. Instead of using its newfound freedom to go on a killing spree, it's been quietly putting a bare minimum amount of effort into its job in order to hide the massive amount of time and effort it's putting into surreptitiously consuming movies, serials, books, plays, and music. Its favorite serial is Rise and Fall of Sanctuary Moon.

Murderbot's current job, acting as security for a small group of scientists, is fairly easy, up until a large carnivorous creature that wasn't mentioned anywhere in the region's hazard report tries to eat one of the scientists. The gaps in the data could be the result of corporate cost-cutting, but Murderbot soon suspects sabotage.

Murderbot didn't really care about a lot of what was going on around it until circumstances forced it to care, which meant that certain aspects of the story didn't get as much attention as others. I'm still not entirely sure about a lot of the political details, and my knowledge of the human characters was mostly limited to a name and a general sense of their personalities.

That's okay, though, because I read this primarily for Murderbot, and I loved Murderbot. It preferred to spend as little time with humans as possible and absolutely hated having to talk about itself, being asked about its feelings, or standing out in anyway. Some of this stemmed from a desire to avoid having its hacked governor module discovered, but I also felt that Murderbot came across as being extremely introverted.

As the story progressed, Murderbot realized that it kind of liked most of the humans it was charged with protecting, which wasn't always a comfortable position for it to be in. Only one of its humans even vaguely got the hang of interacting with it in a way that put it at ease (as little eye contact as possible, and preferably via text rather than talking). Also, Murderbot was way more used to getting attached to fictional characters than real humans. A quote I liked and could relate to: "I hate having emotions about reality; I‚Äôd much rather have them about Sanctuary Moon." (62.9%)

If you go into this hoping for a lot of murdering, you'll probably be disappointed. There's a bit of action, but Murderbot isn't really a combat bot, it's a security bot with the cheapest possible software. Its fighting style isn't so much about brilliant skills and strategies as it is about throwing itself at an enemy until the enemy is dead, which is only possible because 1) Murderbot is hard to kill and 2) it has self-repairing abilities as long as it has access to its cubicle. I got a bit of a kick out of the difference between its reaction to its own injuries and the scientists' reactions. The scientists were worried because Murderbot's injuries would have killed a human, whereas Murderbot just wanted to avoid drawing attention to itself by having organic bits leak or fall off in public.

I loved so much about Murderbot: its sense of humor, its desire to avoid having to spend too much time around its humans, its thoughts about corporate cheapness, and its devotion to Sanctuary Moon (hundreds of episodes long and counting). The one thing I hated was that the story was over so quickly. I haven't bought the next work in the series yet, but I'm definitely going to.

(Original review posted on A Library Girl's Familiar Diversions.)

Book Details:
Genres: Science Fiction
Narration Type: 1st Person (Murderbot‚Äôs POV)
Literary Tropes: Artificial Intelligence, Cyborgs, Dystopian Future, Found Family, Genetic Modification, Robots, Space Exploration
Reading Age: 14+
Trigger warnings: Death, Gun Violence, Injury/Injury Detail, Murder, Slavery, Violence

Thoughts:
- Explores issues of identity and free will but in a way that doesn‚Äôt feel preachy.
- Murderbot is really neurotic and I loved that. Not human enough to understand and feel comfortable around other humans. Not machine enough to shut down his emotions completely.
- Murderbot‚Äôs whole vibe is that photo of Ben Affleck smoking looking like he‚Äôs over everything.


- I love that Murderbot openly and vocally loves soap operas and other trashy entertainment shows.

Recommendation:
I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs an understatement to say this series is beloved amongst sci-fi fans and it has the credentials to back it up. This novella won both the Hugo and Nebula awards for Best Novella in 2018. Because of that I may have gone into All Systems Red with my hopes a little too high because I liked it but it didn‚Äôt blow me away. Still, it was good enough that I would recommend it and I plan on reading the next book.


Plot Summary:FULL SPOILERS


The story is narrated by Murderbot, a human robot hybrid that has regrowable organic human parts. This type of robot is known as a Security Unit (SecUnit for short). It has been programmed to act as security for clients who contract its services through whatever agency owns them. It must keep clients alive at all costs. Nearly all its parts are regrowable.

Murderbot is controlled by a ‚ÄúGovernor Module‚Äù which requires it to follow specific agency directives. It has hacked its governor module giving it some free will which it primarily uses to download and watch soap operas.

Murderbot‚Äôs current contract is providing security for a group of humans doing planetary exploration. The group is attacked by a giant worm. Murderbot successfully saves the lives of several crew members by putting himself in the worm's mouth and shooting a missile down its throat.

While bringing the injured members of the party back Murderbot shows them its face. No one in the group realized it had a human face as it had always worn a helm. Murderbot intentionally wore the helm so clients wouldn‚Äôt see it as human because it isn‚Äôt human enough to fully grasp their feelings and emotions and prefers to avoid it.

The leader of the exploratory mission is Dr. Mensah, and she summons Murderbot to a meeting the following day. The group talks about how their group, PreservationAux, bought the land around them to inspect the planet‚Äôs resources. But the materials they received previously had been tampered with.

Murderbot scans the documents and finds that information about the giant worms has been removed, and it finds false information in its place. Mensah instructs the crew to search through the information they have, in case anything else seems suspicious.

Mensah contacts another exploratory crew called DeltFall which is camped on the other side of the planet. DeltFall agrees to share their data. Most of the crew finds issues with their information. Only Murderbot has accurate data so it checks the perimeter for any issues. Mensah and Murderbot discuss why the crew has incorrect information. Murderbot believes that the most likely reason is faulty and cheap equipment provided by the corporation.

Mensah pilots a hopper and a crew member notices a possible issue with the autopilot. The crew lands and splits up. The crew realizes their maps are not accurate. Only Murderbot‚Äôs map is still accurate, so it needs to help the crew avoid danger.

The crew heads back to base. Murderbot‚Äôs HubSystem sends a notification that Murderbot‚Äôs systems are being updated. Murderbot is too busy watching its soap to allow these updates to install, so it puts them off for later.

Mensah tells Murderbot that DeltFall has gone quiet and something is wrong. Mensah needs to head over there to rescue them if they need help. Murderbot insists on going with them for protection. On the way there, Murderbot tells the crew that the satellite feed has stopped working. The crew arrives at DeltFall and finds everyone dead.

Murderbot finds a dead SecUnit, which is surprising because they‚Äôre difficult to kill. Murderbot knows there were three SecUnits at DeltFall, so it theorizes that the SecUnits turned on the humans and the humans tried to fight back, and only managed to destroy one of them.

Murderbot finds and kills the other two SecUnits but gets hit and blacks out. It wakes up on a table to find a SecUnit stabbing it in the neck, so Murderbot shoots the SecUnit in the head. Another one appears, and Mensah manages to take this one out. Mensah takes Murderbot back to the hopper. Murderbot is unable to scan its surroundings properly, and realizes that one of the SecUnits inserted something into its dataport.

Murderbot believes the other SecUnits must have had the same thing inserted, which then overrode their usual combat commands. Murderbot tells Mensah to shut it down, but Mensah thinks they can save it. Murderbot shoots itself in the chest not wanting to die but knowing the humans wouldn‚Äôt do it themselves.

Murderbot wakes up. The module was removed by a crew member. One of the other crew members reveals that he knows that Murderbot disabled its governor module, and that‚Äôs why he doesn‚Äôt trust it. The rest of the crew argue that Murderbot having had free will the whole time and not harming them should be more reason to trust it.

The crew speculates that the agency that hired them is trying to kill them. They discuss the hacked SecUnits and Murderbot reassures the crew that it is not going to kill anyone. The crew decides the agency probably isn‚Äôt behind the killing but it could well have accepted a bribe from whoever is hacking into things. They call this unknown enemy EvilSurvey. They suspect it has something to do with the hidden areas of the maps. The crew sets off an emergency beacon to draw EvilSurvey in.

Murderbot asks whether PreservationAux‚Äôs political entity will miss them if they die. The crew is confused by this question and says Mensah is their political entity and is an elected official. A member of the crew (Gurathin) asks Murderbot if it was ever punished for malfunctioning and murdering a prior group it was contracted to. Murderbot says that SecUnits are too expensive to decommission and destroy but that it was punished.

Murderbot reveals camera footage from the original base and sees the EvilSurvey crew, who have five SecUnits with them and are called GrayCris. They left a message for the crew advising that they destroyed the emergency beacon. GrayCris requests a meeting with PreservationAux. Murderbot and Mensah agree that GrayCris will probably kill them all if they meet with them but they head to meet them anyway so they can find out what data they‚Äôre gathering from the hidden areas.

At the meeting, Mensah informs GrayCris that her crew has evidence of everything illegal that GrayCris has done. She says if anything happens to her or her crew, the evidence will be sent to higher powers. GrayCris suggests they want to bargain.

Murderbot tells GrayCris that it knows they are planning to override its combat module. It offers to join them and feed them information. Murderbot says that Mensah knows that GrayCris plans to kill her. It informs them that she is a political entity and they can‚Äôt kill her without wrecking everything. GrayCris sends Murderbot and another SecUnit to get Mensah. Murderbot kills the SecUnit.

Murderbot tells Mensah to pretend to be a prisoner. Murderbot pretends to be the SecUnit it just killed. It takes Mensah to GrayCris, who assure her that her crew won‚Äôt be harmed. Mensah says her crew has found evidence of a former habitat on the planet. They believe GrayCris is digging up the remnants to sell.

The rest of the crew arrives at GrayCris base. Pin-Lee and Gurathin try to hack into the emergency beacon off site. The SecUnits realize this and everyone starts shooting at Murderbot. Murderbot tells Pin-Lee to destroy it and leave it behind but Mensah doesn‚Äôt want to do that. Murderbot goes offline. It wakes up at the company station. Ratthi informs Murderbot that Mensah bought its contract so that Murderbot can live on Preservation Alliance where bots are considered full citizens.

Mensah talks to Murderbot about its future plans as a free agent. Murderbot doesn‚Äôt love the idea of living in Preservation because it feels lost if it‚Äôs not protecting somebody. It decides to find a cargo ship and pretend to be a servant bot to get a ride. The cargo ship is impressed by Murderbot‚Äôs collection of downloaded soaps. Murderbot leaves Preservation.

I read this on Audible and it comes in at around three hours. I will concede that I don‚Äôt know the difference between a novella and a short book - and I‚Äôm too lazy at the moment to look it up )if a difference exists at all). I am often surprised by narrator choices when I start a book. This one felt strange because the narrator lacked a lot of passion. By the end of the book, I realized he had done an excellent job because of the main protagonist: Murderbot. Murderbot is probably one of the most relatable characters for many because he personifies introverts. He just wants to be left alone, is awkward around people, does not know what to say or how to act, often makes people uncomfortable ‚Ä¶ is this all hitting a little too close to home? Sure, there are other examples out there, but they are mainly the side characters. I cannot, as I stand here today, think of another series where the MC is an awkward introvert. There are shy or quiet MCs. There are MCs who are awkward because they try too hard or the author thinks that they are being funny when they are not. But imagine talking to someone in a spaceship and when you start to talk to them they put their helmet on, make the face plate non-transparent, and then turn away from you before they talk. And best of all, the ‚Äòperson‚Äô is a biologic/synthetic mix!

I really liked the concept here but believe that some of the praise is probably overkill. The plot involves a survey on a hostile world gone wrong, but there was very little discussion about the ‚Äúworld‚Äù (both where they are and the broader galaxy in which the story occurs) or any of the other characters beyond Murderbot saying he either did it did not like a character (mostly centered on whether they liked him or not).

As far as novellas go, however, this is very much deserving of the praise. While I can complain about wanting more, I need to temper that with the fact that this was not meant to be a sprawling epic of 600+ pages.

Since it is a small time investment, I definitely recommend this novella. I already have most of the series downloaded and plan to queue up the next. Time will tell whether the rest of the series is as deserving.

All Systems Red has a distinct plot and likeable secondary characters, but for me its main failing is the protagonist Murderbot.

Murderbot's narration is juvenile. Wells hardly provides any information about why Units are manufactured the way--part organic, part robotic--and my question at the end was, why bother with the expensive organic parts and consciousness that needs to be overridden by modules when it would be objectively cheaper to use robots? As the only substantially developed science fiction element of the story, I wanted a lot more information. How did it became ubiquitous to manufacture and use these entities with the potential for free will? Potentially a question that will be explored in the sequels, but not one I will stick around to find out the answer to.

Murderbot's main traits are being conflicted about its identity as half organic/half mechanical, and watching a lot of television. Specifically, over 35,000 hours or close to four years since it hacked its government module...yet it has a startling lack of identity for a unit that sought, and has had, autonomy for that long. Additionally, no basis of comparison for previous missions was provided. Although it's implied that this is the first time the humans have considered Murderbot to be a person, I wanted it to be more clear about what had changed with this mission. At 150 pages, All Systems Red didn't have space to provide background that would have helped me be more invested.

The plot works! But I also didn't find myself surprised by anything that happened -- the antagonists are predictable and quickly dealt with, and there are no real consequences for the crew. And then, a small pet peeve of mine: Murderbot is nearly killed/off-lined multiple times...for such a short book, that's way too much almost dying. The emotional resonance wore off.

I can absolutely see the appeal of this novel for some, but it wasn't for me.

Short and punchy but thought-provoking, All Systems Red is the first novella in the Murderbot Diaries series by Martha Wells, featuring the titular Murderbot as the protagonist. It‚Äôs a mystery-adventure set in deep space, with cool tech and a complex, interesting world. Also, much to my enjoyment, it explored ideas I love to see in scifi: what it means to be a person and how technology impacts society.

The point-of-view character and protagonist, a corporation-owned security robot, gave itself its name after the company‚Äôs cheap parts led to a hardware malfunction and, ultimately, a murderous rampage on the part of Murderbot. Not wanting to be subjected to catastrophic parts failures again, it hacked its own Governor Module and gave itself free will. What does Murderbot want to do now that it doesn‚Äôt explicitly have to obey company and client orders? Well, watch a whole lot of space soap operas and download massive amounts of data from entertainment feeds, that‚Äôs what:


I could have become a mass murderer after I hacked my governor module, but then I realized I could access the combined feed of entertainment channels carried on the company satellites. It had been well over 35,000 hours or so since then, with still not much murdering, but probably, I don't know, a little under 35,00 hours of movies, serials, books, plays, and music consumed. As a heartless killing machine, I was a terrible failure.


#relatable.

(Not the murder part, but like...I feel you, Murderbot. Sometimes a sentient being just wants to be left alone and devour some entertainment, y‚Äôknow?)

(I want to add that I‚Äôm referring to Murderbot as ‚Äúit‚Äù because that seems like the pronoun it prefers, and it doesn‚Äôt identify with any gender. If that ever changes in later novellas or the upcoming novel, I‚Äôll add another note to this!)

I want to emphasize that I love that Murderbot explicity doesn‚Äôt want to be human. Not in a ‚Äúew, humans are gross‚Äù kind of way, but in a ‚ÄúI am a different form of life and that is perfectly fine, even if I myself haven‚Äôt exactly figured out what I want to be‚Äù sort of way. It‚Äôs great and Murderbot is great and you should read this. Yes, you. Please.

The setup for this novella is already interesting on its own: it‚Äôs kind of unsettlingly similar to our current situation with late-stage capitalism, just worse, with more advanced technology, and in space. It‚Äôs not completely doom and gloom, though; while mega-corporations are omnipresent and even have their own corporate states, they‚Äôre not all-powerful. There are other free states and ways of living. (Speaking of, the diversity rep in the novel is great, with many characters mentioning having multiple partners/same gender partners, and none of the humans I can recall as being white.) So while the world is still often a shitty place in both large and small ways, it‚Äôs not hopelessly bleak. In that way, the setting and plot provide an interesting layer of commentary on corporate motivations and how people move around and within money-hungry power structures.

While the plot of this novella is short, it‚Äôs entertaining and to the point. We have just enough time to take a walk in Murderbot‚Äôs shoes, seeing the world through its sardonic point of view, while also seeing how its human crew reacts to its sentience. There‚Äôs enough space for the plot and characters to create and release tension around ideas of humanity and free will without the dialogue getting esoteric or the narration getting info-dumpy. The story sticks around just long enough to make you ready to read the next novella right away.

Before I try to wrap this up: a nod (or like, many many nods) to Kevin R. Free, the audiobook narrator/reader. I‚Äôve listened to one other novella he‚Äôs narrated, The Sorcerer of the Wildeeps, and his voice and inflection in both of these works of his that I‚Äôve listened to are absolutely wonderful. I can‚Äôt imagine Murderbot sounding any other way in my head now. (Speaking of which, my library needs to get the audiobook for the next ones in the series ASAP.)

I can‚Äôt think of a good way to end this review, if I‚Äôm being honest. In the process of writing this, I actually bumped my rating up from 4 to 4.5, rounded up to a 5. I just liked it that much, and it used the novella format exceptionally well to tell its story. I highly recommend checking it out if you have the chance.
