You can find my review on my blog by clicking here.

Winner of the 2017 Nebula Award for Best Novella, All Systems Red is one of those books that was impossible to ignore with its buzz being almost omnipresent since its release. The praise it was getting was unquestionable and its blurb alone had me hooked and utterly curious to find out what all the fuzz was about. Dying to try novellas again, this series seemed like the perfect re-entry point for me. I mean, how could anything go wrong with an android called a ‚ÄúMurderbot‚Äù being the main character? In the end, there‚Äôs no denying that this turned out to be addictive and engaging. The journey of this Murderbot is one that develops steadily with a satisfying balance between action and humour.

What exactly is All Systems Red about though? This is the story of a SecUnit tasked to protect a team of scientists on their expedition in dangerous fields. Unlike other androids, this one however hacked its governor module (the very component that allows humans to control them) and successfully got its hands on what we would call ‚Äúfree will‚Äù. Instead of turning rampant or escaping its faith as a SecUnit, this android has assigned itself the purpose of protecting its clients at all cost. Remaining inconspicuous among the team is however a struggle, but whenever it can, it will find ways to avoid contact and find peace in isolation. It‚Äôs when things go awry with another crew of scientists that this android and its clients find themselves looking for answers, but also pernicious trouble, with unknown danger staring right back at them.

For a first installment in The Murderbot Diaries series, All Systems Red does a comprehensive portrayal of artificial intelligence in ways that have rarely been conducted in the past. Instead of having a robot who wants to become human, we find ourselves in front of one that is human. Its personality is incredibly relatable and far more human than some of us could ever be, but this Murderbot only wishes to be left alone in its introverted lifestyle. Stuck trying to hide its true self from a crew of scientists who would never truly understand it, it finds satisfaction in accomplishing its role as a Company-supplied security android in order to stay away from any potential trouble that the knowledge of its free will would have upon it.

Interestingly enough, this Murderbot is never referred to as a male or a female throughout the story. While I saw it as a woman all along, I was far too often able to connect myself to its most deepest desires (i.e. being left alone to enjoy some space soap opera). Martha Wells‚Äô writing style also proves to be impeccable in All Systems Red and effortlessly manages to give this android a voice of its own. Without the focus on its gender, she was able to bring the reader to explore subtler details that helped further accentuate the android‚Äôs peculiar situation in a world of humans that only sees things from their own selfish position.

All Systems Red is a fascinating novella that follows an introverted android in its quest to embrace its true-self while trying to respect its purposes as a Murderbot. What it will come to realize will however force it to embark on an adventure that it might not ever be ready for, as both its purpose and its rights as an android with free will are tested.

Thank you to Raincoast Books and Tor.com / Tom Doherty Associates for sending me a copy for review!

Yours truly,

All System Red if u were to sum it up with few words it would be a short but fun ride.

This will be a short review as it only took basically a day to finish this novella. Plus, I wouldn't be quite harsh on it as I have a different expectation of a just above 30k novella compared to like 100k - 400k novel. For what its intents to achieve I think Murderbot does its job well, which is liking the named protagonist.

Edit: I should rephrase I don't think I gave Martha Wells enough credit but Murderbot, not just a likable protagonist. I think She does a good job of fleshing him out. Showcasing AI in a unique perspective. The Shy aspect of Murderbot is pretty great, it does feel distinct.

As from the introduction it states


‚Äú I COULD HAVE BECOME a mass murderer after I hacked my governor module, but then I realized I could access the combined feed of entertainment channels carried on the company satellites. It had been well over 35,000 hours or so since then, with still not much murdering, but probably, I don‚Äôt know, a little under 35,000 hours of movies, serials, books, plays, and music consumed. As a heartless killing machine, I was a terrible failure.‚Äù



Which I mean is a great hook to a series, the status quo of series of this nature already bent. I do think booktube has given this novella or series (well I should read the rest to see if that is true) but a false expectation. This is nothing deep or found thought-provoking which contrast to what I been reading recently is not a bad thing. It delivers on it being a fun adventure all around. Besides the opening paragraph, I won‚Äôt give anything else regarding the plot as it probably spoils half this novella. The plot in general nothing to hit home about which is fine. The characters voices are not that distinct not even about being well fleshed out as you got like 3-4 humans and 30k word count, you got to be realistic in terms of priorities. Just hoped voices were a bit more distinct. The prose well does its job in its first-person, especially at the end its well contextualised. They some distance to the writing style which is quite clear and to the point which reflects on the character well enough. The Worldbuilding I don‚Äôt have too many thoughts on but for a novella and what it sets out I am not going to be critical about that aspect, plus murderbot doesn‚Äôt give a shit about the world so that‚Äôs why we don‚Äôt know too much. However, I do like the information they gave about the murderbot units.


‚ÄúDid I mean a cilia or was that something else? They don‚Äôt give murderbots decent education modules on anything except murdering, and even those are the cheap versions.‚Äù


Cheaply made been a reoccurring thing from the beginning of the novella. But what is interesting is the organic material aspect. All featuring the same generic face as you would in an RPG. Also, the emotional side of Murderbot leaves me curious about certain aspects of the world. I do think the sequels will be better just considering how the ending of this book has opened certain things where I am unsure where it's heading.

In Conclusion, this is no outstanding novella or whatever its just some lighthearted fun entertainment that u can consume within 2-4 hrs max. I do think the concept of murderbot is cooler than what actually displayed like the opening lines are great, but I definitely wait and see; interested in continuing the adventure in the future.

6/10

Changing my score for this novella still judging it as a novella and not a novel. But more I think about it and what you can do in small fiction, unsure if I can confidently give it a 6.5 so yeah it's now 6/10

A story set on a distant planet and focusing on some kind of robot (or SecUnit) in charge of security for a team of scientists just couldn‚Äôt go wrong. I actually started reading this novella without reading anything about it. I was expecting a bit more action or violence since the series has the word ‚ÄúMurderbot‚Äù in it, which (surprisingly) led me to believe there would be lots of murder. Still, I was nicely surprised when I dived in a story that really focuses on what‚Äôs happening inside the main character‚Äôs head and the relationship (or absence of) between him and the other characters.

The first page (yes it‚Äôs a first page, I set the font size very large haha) did the trick, I was sold:

Everything about this book was completely out of my comfort zone and not at all what I would gravitate towards, but I enjoyed it so much. The protagonist was more endearing than most other protagonists I've read, despite being part-robot. The storytelling was solid, and the plot was such a breath of fresh air. This is a 4 to 4.5* read for me, with the only thing stopping it from being a 5* simply being that I zoned out sometimes during the more sci-fi-ish bits, which was sometimes quite dense for a sci-fi layperson like me.

This is a pretty short book, but it took me probably more than half of it to figure out exactly what was going on in terms of the world, the plot, and even just the names for everything (I'm just not used to so much sci-fi and tech jargon in my books). Despite that, the book still managed to be engaging enough almost right from the start, primarily due to the the protagonist's engaging voice - it might be a Murderbot, but it's also just a really shy, introverted entity that just wants to hide behind its opaque face shield thing all day, watch the amazing amount of TV serials it's downloaded, and not have to talk to humans, especially not about its feelings. Honestly, kind of relatable.

Murderbot (it doesn't really have an actual name, so we'll just call it that) is contracted out to a group of scientists and explorers, presumably in some spacefaring civilisation. It's actually a SecUnit (a security unit) that is rented out to these expeditions to protect people from hostile alien lifeforms (or other humans, I suppose). We kinda sorta get to know the scientists in Murderbot's group and they play a big role in the actual plot of this particular story, but the book being as short as it is means that we don't get the time to actually know these characters very well. While I'd love to hear more of them in the subsequent instalments, the main attraction of the story really is Murderbot and its perspective so I wouldn't say this at all detracts from the beauty of the book.

The group and Murderbot discover another expedition of scientists brutally murdered, and then it's a rollercoaster ride from there as they try to figure out who's behind that massacre before the culprits catch up with them to do the same.

What I particularly liked about the storytelling is that, even though we get the events from Murderbot's perspective, we can't help also feeling a little distrustful of Murderbot and wondering if it might be an unreliable narrator. Does that mean I'm siding with the humans over the non-human, even though we are seeing the story through the latter's eyes? What makes Murderbot, who is only part-robot with "organic parts" (i.e. human bits, since it has an actual face and other human organs, which it is able to regenerate when injured or even regrow when it's completely blasted off), different from the augmented humans in this story, when both of them are able to access feeds and information systems presumably via their brains alone? Tl;dr this is a sci-fi story but I find that it made me ask a lot of pretty interesting questions about the nature of robots and artificial intelligence, especially when juxtaposed with human emotions. And the book didn't bald-facedly ask those questions, just set things up so that readers might be provoked into asking these for themselves. That's damn good writing there.

Overall, highly recommended for anyone, especially if you're a sci-fi fan. But even if you're like me and not familiar with sci-fi at all, this still remains a great read.

Read for the second time. Enjoyed and appreciated it once again. In fact I'm raising my grade slightly to 4.25 stars.


Nov 17, 2020

4 / 4.25 stars

This novella launched Martha Wells‚Äôs Murderbot Diaries series. These books have been raved about both here and at other review sites, my social media feeds, and by one of my real life friends. I‚Äôm late to the party but I finally picked it up.

The narrator, an android ‚ÄúSecUnit,‚Äù has dubbed themself Murderbot. Their job is to defend and protect their leasers (Murderbot is owned by a mega-corporation referred to as ‚Äúthe Company‚Äù). Although the human members of the planetary research team currently leasing Murderbot don‚Äôt know it, Murderbot has hacked themself and is, to a degree, free to do as they please (consuming soap opera episodes is high on the agenda). But there‚Äôs a wrinkle: Murderbot can‚Äôt let anyone know they now have free will. If the humans learn of it and tell, Murderbot will be reprogrammed.

Murderbot and the team they are guarding are on a mission that goes bad when a crater reveals itself to be the lair of a giant killer worm and one of the team members is injured and nearly dies. As the team looks into it further, it becomes evident that their data was compromised so as to lead them to think the crater was safe. Someone has it in for the team, and it is the Murderbot‚Äôs job to defend the people they refer to as ‚Äúmy humans.‚Äù But how can Murderbot find out who the killer it, or even who they (Murderbot) are, without being found out themself?

This was a sweet novella, but I think my expectations may have been too high due to all the buzz. Murderbot was a lovable character and I liked most of the humans working on the team. Some of the best aspects of the story were the interpersonal dynamics, with Murderbot trying to figure out how to relate to the team and the team trying to work out how to relate to Murderbot. I liked the way Murderbot‚Äôs character developed with each interaction and how their relationships with the others shifted as a result. The ending was clever and I loved it.

The mystery plot was suspenseful but ultimately not 100% there because‚Äî


‚Äîit relied on the incompetence of the villain(s). When villains don‚Äôt act according to their self-interest or when they don‚Äôt know what their self-interest is, it makes a villain(s)‚Äô motive shaky, and it also makes the villain(s) less of a challenge for the protagonist to defeat.

All Systems Red was also‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt want to say slight because it was just a novella. It was not slight for a novella at all, but I have also read novellas with more substance. This goes back to my high expectations. But it‚Äôs still looking like it will be a good series.

I love big stories pack into little pages.

A conflicted AI with a past so tragic he calls himself Murderbot...but that's private. As long as no one discovers he's hacked his governor module, he can pretend he's just doing his job as security for some boring scientists collecting samples on a boring planet and watch endless TV shows when no one is looking.

But what will happen when the humans learn his secret?

This story was a lot of fun. Scyfy. Mystery. Sabotage. Reluctant heroes. Alien planet. Robots. Feelings? How does great Scyfy packed into a book that can be read in a day sound?

Ya--you're going to want to check this one out.

Books 2, 3, and 4 will be published in 2018. I'll be reading them.

Watch out for some grown-up language.¬† Older teens and adults will appreciate this one the most.

Happy reading!

Series Review:

Ode to Murderbot

Murderbot, Murderbot!
Fierce friend, Fierce foe,
How do I love thee?
You must read on to know.

Murderbot, Murderbot!
You are a machine designed to kill,
But you hacked your own governor module.
Are you deadly still?

Murderbot, Murderbot!
Yes, you remain lethal, now that you've gone rogue.
Now? Now you make your own choice. And what do you do?
You want to be alone, hiding from your feelings, viewing TV shows no longer vogue.

Murderbot, Murderbot!
If you only understood--people will relate to you! It is true!
You are a killing machine with social anxiety and a conscience.
What to do, what do to?

Murderbot, Murderbot!
Yes, the choice is hard, but you're a survivor!
Discover who you are! Learn your place! Believe in yourself!
You are a bad-guy-butt-kicking robot Macgyver!

Murderbot, Murderbot!
You think you're just Murderbot, you don't even expect a "hello,"
but the lesson, the one lesson to learn is this:
You're more human than than most humans I know.

So, obviously, I don't have a future in poetry...but I really loved The Murderbot Diaries! The four short books are really four parts to one story arc, so don't expect to read out of order or stop somewhere in the middle.

Watch out for some robot violence and quite a bit of heavy swearing. If it weren't for that, I'd recommend this series to everyone. Instead I'll recommend it to adults who don't mind colorful, four-letter expletives.

Happy reading!

Oh, this wasn't what I wanted, this was what I needed. The dark and serious cover didn't prepare me in the slightest for how humorous and amusing this journey through space would be and I loved it!




All System Red is a novella told through the eyes of Murderbot ‚Äì a cyborg that was programmed by the Company, which organises and approves all planetary missions, to accompany those flying out. Murderbot has managed to hack its module though and is now able to operate wild and freely. Theoretically at least. In practice, the android turns out to be a pretty self-aware and socially awkward creature, only wanting to find out who he really is, which doesn't seem possible when his and a team of scientists' mission go awry.

Murderbot is a wonderful character. He's so scornful in the way he thinks about humans that it's really quite funny. He's obviously there to protect the folks he's around, but he turns out to be pretty lazy, secretly spending most of his time watching soap operas and doing the bare minimum in order to keep the mission afloat. The combination of being a grumpy old piece of metal and at the same time an insufferable softie just works incredibly well.

The plot is short and sweet and leaves you wanting more. So while Murderbot is definitely the reason this is so special, the actual events happening are rather gripping as well. Things go very wrong at some point and one of the highlights of reading this was definitely when the qualified and trained team of scientists admits that their approach to solving the problems at hand was based on what they know from TV shows. With less than 200 pages, this really is too slender a volume to go stale at any point and I'm instead extremely curious to find out how things are going to develop from here and will probably jump onto the next instalment of this series in no time.

Based on that kind of title who would have expected a story about a security robot that hacks it's own governing module so can watch tv all day instead of doing its job? I know I didn't. And boy was this story great fun.

Sometime in the future, the Company approves and supplies all planetary missions. As standard procedure all teams are accompanied by Company provided security androids, called SecUnits, a regulatory 1 android per 10 humans. On a distant planet, a research team is conducting surveys of the surface. Sure, there have been strange computer glitches from time to time, all perfectly normal considering programming contracts tend to go to the lowest bidder. That is right up until a neighboring mission goes dark and the scientists are determined to find out what happened.

Clocking in at just over 150 pages, Wells does an impressive job. The plot takes off immediately, with the researchers and Murderbot finding themselves in a highly dangerous situation they never expected. On top of that she weaves in great characterization for Murderbot. Being an android who is finds dealing with humans uncomfortable and slightly annoying, preferring instead just watch them on tv, it's highly relatable to anyone who was an awkward teen growing up or just on those days when you'd rather not deal with people. Though Murderbot tries to come across as apathetic, I think it does care underneath it all. The downside to having such limited space is the rest of the characters aren't nearly so fleshed out. That's ok though since this is Murderbot's story.

Well written and entertaining, this was a satisfying short read.

I got totally schooled by this book. When I finished it I hated it. I wrote a review complaining about how -- except for the protagonist -- all of the characters were just names on a page, not real characters, completely without personality. I was about to post a 2-star review. Then my wife got home and I started bitching up a storm about how shitty the book was. I read it out of her Kindle library, see. And she‚Äôs like: ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs a bot! The story is told in the first person from the perspective of a bot. So the narrator is an anti-social, non-human construct. The characters have no personality to you because they have no personality to the bot that‚Äôs telling you the story.‚Äù My mouth snapped shut. Silence. I‚Äôm thinking: holy shit. I had to sit down. She was right. Suddenly this book that I hated unto vituperation struck me as soaring genius. Then I started thinking about the courage it took Wells as a writer to intentionally write something shitty in order to faithfully reflect the perspective of a character. OMG. I forgot to step back is what happened. I‚Äôve felt incensed like this about a piece of literature before, but in that case I paused and asked myself: Hey, was that on purpose, maybe? And when I realized the offending particulars were indeed by design, I understood the trick of the story. I didn‚Äôt ask that question this time. There is some prejudice in me against genre lit, I think. Without that prejudice I would have taken a breath and thought it through. I need to address this blind spot. Schooled by Martha Wells (and my wife). Five stars for bravery. Three stars in general. Four solid stars.

Oh, Avatar meets Asimov meets wifi. That‚Äôs how I sum it up.

When you read a book in one sitting, you know it's good. All Systems Red, by Martha Wells, is the first book in The Murderbot Diaries - a campy and schlocky sounding series name. I read it for a quick science fiction hit, and came away quite surprised, and excited to continue the series. Wells has packed a slim and short science fiction novella with lots of heart, detail and style. The book follows Murderbot - self titled name of a rogue security android who has hacked it own governing module in order to think freely. It spends most of its time watching entertainment serials while it pretends to continue its role - providing security for surveying teams on alien worlds. The job is mostly boring, and Murderbot enjoys the downtime, as well as its own crippling social anxiety, and hides behind its robotic side to avoid human contact. However, when its current job goes dangerous, and a conspiracy begins to form, Murderbot feels compelled to protect its current human employers.

The book is simple in many ways - the story is straightforward, for example, and most of the characters outside Murderbot are only minimal factors. Even so, so much story, character and heart is packed into Muderbot and its thought process. The setting and world building are also fantastic. This is my favourite part of science fiction. I love an author that can pack in style and substance, and build a world that I can lose myself in. Wells has done a fabulous job, and in hundreds of pages less than most authors. This book is a fun read. It's quick, stylistic, and a good hit of science fiction. An easy recommendation from me, and certainly the best science fiction novel I have read in a while.

To make a hard-boiled story work, against any background, you need two things: a first-person narrator with a distinctive, preferable world-weary and cynical, voice, and a good mystery. This first "Murderbot" novella is therefore a working hard-boiled story. Someone has slaughtered the scientists at one planetary survey base, and the inhabitants of the other, with their security robot (aka the titular Murderbot), have to figure out who and why, while also trying to stay alive. Murderbot's unexpected musings on humanity, the society that created him, and the nature of free will provide the philosophical and thematic base of the story, but this is a locked-room (or base) mystery with a corking good supporting cast and a suspenseful ending. It bodes well for the rest of the series.

Murderbot is so me! Haha. In the sense that 9 out of 10 times I would rather waste time binge watching Fringe than to interact with humans, and that work is sometimes tedious and gets so dull or repetitive that I need to have my favorite movies playing in the background to keep me entertained but at the same time I'm tied to this feeling that I can't step away from my job because RESPONSIBILITIES ya know. I just really love this ‚Äúbot person‚Äù main character who is truly relatable with its existential bot angst.

While the plot itself is not that mysterious and rather straightforward, it generated enough tension for me to care and worry about the fate of Murderbot and the humans under its care. However, what I found so brilliant about this book is the author's portrayal of a cyborg construct that, while logical in its approach to doing its job, behaves emotionally very much like a traumatized human child.

I mean think about it. This is a bot with some clone-tech-generated organic parts basically making it partly human, that was created essentially to kill, had spent the entirety of its life killing other beings, and whose governor module became corrupted so it went rogue and committed mass murder. After which, it was reformatted and brought back to service another security contract. This is the human equivalent of sending a person to serve in multiple wars and exposing them to the trauma of having to extinguish multiple lives while constantly being exposed to the threat of being killed yourself‚Ä¶ and then while you're still carrying all that PTSD you are placed again in a similar situation that can very well trigger your past trauma. No wonder it is self-hating and calls itself Murderbot. (NB: psychological analyses of war veterans have documented that committing violence can be as traumatizing and dehumanizing as being violated, at least in the cases of soldiers who felt like they had no choice but to carry out instructions and do whatever was necessary to survive the battlefield.)

On top of that, because it wasn't that long ago that its governor module was hacked, Murderbot is still emotionally either a child or a young teenager who is grappling with its existence as an actual sentient entity with its own free will. It never experienced a childhood, so it never got itself gradually socialized to humans or other sentient beings under the guidance of caring adults, therefore it found face-to-face human interaction awkward and anxiety-inducing. On this contract, with the PreservationAux team, Murderbot is essentially navigating an awkward high school phase while possibly still at the emotional maturity of a kindergartner. The fact that it found a comforting parental figure in Dr Mensah is also interesting. The different ways that the human crew members responded to Murderbot after they've seen it without armor, looking ‚Äúnormal‚Äù aka humanlike, were very well-written. The general impulse in everyone EXCEPT the sole augmented human in the group was to treat Murderbot as a person ‚Äì that irony is definitely not lost on me. It also triggered several conversations among the humans whether it's morally right to keep bots working for humans without giving the bots a choice about it. Of course, when Murderbot was dragged into such conversations it was excruciatingly painful for it to contemplate its place in the general scheme of things. It most definitely wasn't ready for that conversation yet as it was only just beginning to explore what existing as a person even means.

I truly enjoyed this imaginative, speculative exploration of what being a newly self-aware robot might be like. There exist many questions underneath this novella: questions of sentience, free will, slavery, self-identity, self-hatred, discrimination, social inequality, the military industrial complex, etc. Looking forward to binge reading the entire series!

No wonder it is self-hating and calls itself Murderbot. (NB: psychological analyses of war veterans have documented that committing violence can be as traumatizing and dehumanizing as being violated, at least in the cases of soldiers who felt like they had no choice but to carry out instructions and do whatever was necessary to survive the battlefield.)

On top of that, because it wasn't that long ago that its governor module was hacked, Murderbot is still emotionally either a child or a young teenager who is grappling with its existence as an actual sentient entity with its own free will. It never experienced a childhood, so it never got itself gradually socialized to humans or other sentient beings under the guidance of caring adults, therefore it found face-to-face human interaction awkward and anxiety-inducing. On this contract, with the PreservationAux team, Murderbot is essentially navigating an awkward high school phase while possibly still at the emotional maturity of a kindergartner. The fact that it found a comforting parental figure in Dr Mensah is also interesting. The different ways that the human crew members responded to Murderbot after they've seen it without armor, looking ‚Äúnormal‚Äù aka humanlike, were very well-written. The general impulse in everyone EXCEPT the sole augmented human in the group was to treat Murderbot as a person ‚Äì that irony is definitely not lost on me. It explores the ethics of sentient robotics and follows a self-aware security droid known as "Murderbot." Murderbot is my hero. If you've ever felt that humans are dumb and annoying and illogical and always getting in the way and more trouble than they're worth, you'll be able to relate to Murderbot. And yet, despite Murderbot's idle fantasies of killing all the humans, Murderbot finds these particular humans not so bad (mostly) and for some reason keeps saving them instead of killing them. After all, keeping people alive is Murderbot's job, and Murderbot likes having a job to do, especially when it's the job that it was designed for, and a job that it's very, VERY good at. If only they would stop mouthing off and giving dumb orders or whatever... and they definitely should NOT be trying to make friends with Murderbot.

I'm an insurance attorney, and one aspect of this story that really tickles me is that Murderbot works for what is essentially an insurance company in the most traditional sense. The original Lloyd's of London was founded to insure costly, high-risk sea voyages to distant lands, and the bond company that owns/employs Murderbot is in the exact same business... only in space. Most of what they do, from insisting that security units like Murderbot go along on the expedition, to emergency extraction services, is just loss prevention.

Treat this novella like a long short story, and you can avoid the disappointment that so many readers feel when they want it to be a novel and find that it's not. After all, it has a perfect short-story ending that reminds me intensely of the ending of The Matrix.

In fact, this story reminds me of The Matrix in more than one way. Like Neo & co in The Matrix, Murderbot looks superficially human as long as it hides its inorganic parts under clothing, but is stronger and faster than any human, and has almost supernatural combat abilities, at least compared to a normal human. I keep picturing the fight scenes (and there are a lot of them) in a Matrix-style "bullet time" slo-mo, where Murderbot does wild stuff like wall runs, disarming multiple enemies at insane speeds, and charging an armed enemy so fast it can simply grab the weapon and point it back in the enemy's own face. Of course, Murderbot is generally trying not to draw attention to itself, so it tries to keep that sort of thing to a minimum... or at least make sure there are no surviving witnesses.

All four Murderbot novellas deserve to be collected as an omnibus (and this review is really a review of all of them), because they really are somewhat like sections of a complete novel. In each, Murderbot goes on a relatively self-contained adventure where for some reason the humans are always trying to get themselves killed (and some are trying to kill Murderbot - bad idea). Even worse, they keep doing things that force Murderbot to start examining its own personhood, when all it really wants to do is download and watch more media so it can avoid its real-life problems. (Boy, doesn't that feel familiar in 2020.) But each new adventure ties into the larger story of Murderbot, Dr. Mensah, PerservationAux, and the things that happened both in that first novella and in Murderbot's own past. In the fourth novella, things will come full circle.

Note: I could die happy if I never hear the word "shoved" again.

Audio Notes: I've heard some people say they didn't like Kevin Free's narration that much, but I thought he was quite good. He gives Murderbot just the right amount of snark (i.e., a massive amount) in its own internal narrative, but it plays things mostly low-key when interacting with the humans. You'll see that change some throughout all four novellas, as MB gets more accustomed to expressing itself in a human style. My main gripe is that too often, I found it impossible to distinguish between MB's own internal dialog and its actual verbal dialog with people around it. I've heard other audio narrators make this distinction really, really well, so I know it can be done. My other little tiny gripe is that at several points, Free insists on pronouncing "Hostile One" with the wrong emphasis, so it sounds like "one who is hostile" rather than, "the Hostile that I've designated Number One."

Does it pass the Bechdel test? Yes! I'd say a solid half the characters in each book are female, and in Rogue Protocol, I think women significantly outnumbered men. Now there's a change of pace.

Excuse me, I have to go vread it again.

UPDATE: On my third read, my giddiness finally subsided enough to notice a couple of flaws:

Descriptions of environments are... sparse, to put it kindly. But that's not as much of a flaw in a story like this, where the whole story is told from Murderbot's POV, and MB simply doesn't care about things like that, except in the sense that it relates to security. And much of the story takes place in cyberspace, as Murderbot is constantly interacting with people and other AIs through the "feed." But if this were a "fantastic things and places" type of story rather than an "inner monologue of an AI" story, I'd be really annoyed by it.

There's a point in Book 2 where Murderbot alters its physical appearance to help evade scans that would identify it as a SecUnit. I wondered how it was going to deal with the simple fact that much of its innards are non-organic, and changing the way it looks on the outside probably wouldn't even defeat a simple x-ray scan of the type of we have in airports on 2020 RealEarth.

4.5 stars rounded up to 5 stars!


I loved All Systems Red. The very first chapter let me know that I was really going to enjoy this ride. And I did.


I COULD HAVE BECOME a mass murderer after I hacked my governor module, but then I realized I could access the combined feed of entertainment channels carried on the company satellites. It had been well over 35,000 hours or so since then, with still not much murdering, but probably, I don‚Äôt know, a little under 35,000 hours of movies, serials, books, plays, and music consumed. As a heartless killing machine, I was a terrible failure.
-p1



Murderbot is incredibly snarky ‚Äì which I appreciate. Murderbot is a SecUnit construct ‚Äì part organic, part bionic ‚Äì with no sexual parts, making it agendered. It does not have a name other than what it named itself: Murderbot. It does not think of itself with as a gender but I decided it was a she (in my head). Murderbot, like most of us, is contemptuous of humans and irritated by them ‚Äì she/it just wants to be left alone so it could stream. 35,000 hours of entertainment thus far ‚Äì with many, many more series to glom.

Oh, how I understand you, Murderbot. That irritation you feel each time someone interrupts your streaming with some inane human request or activity? I am there with you. That annoyance you feel when you have to pause a show to deal with ‚Äúreal life‚Äù is quite the same way I feel when I have to put down my book(s) and go to work. The desire you feel to murder someone because they can‚Äôt understand that YES, You ARE busy consuming things you want to consume? It‚Äôs like an itch you can‚Äôt scratch...and plus who has time for murder when you can get back to reading as soon as they leave you alone?

Murderbot was created and is owned by ‚Äúthe company.‚Äù IDK exactly who/what the company is ‚Äì there is no real explanation. The company seems to be some large private conglomerate that has a monopoly on [new] planet exploration. The company then sells sections of the planet along with survey specs to different exploration groups looking for new flora and fauna. In order to buy these sections (and the ability to explore and possibly discover new things) the exploration groups must also purchase [only] company supplies, computer equipment, life support & Communications (HubSystem) and SecUnits (android security units). The SecUnits are required and gives the company an additional edge: the SecUnits + the HubSystem records EVERYTHING (no privacy at all). And like all good conglomerates, the company buys everything as cheap as possible AND they farm all recordings for as much data as possible and then sells it to the highest bidder.

Murderbot is a SecUnit who is completely self-aware (IDK if any of the others are but I get the feeling they are). Murderbot hacked it‚Äôs ‚Äúgovernor module‚Äù as soon as it could do so, making it autonomous. This means that Murderbot decides when and if it will download updates as well what it will attend to. Mostly, it wants to attend to the series it‚Äôs currently downloaded.

Murderbot develops an unlikely attachment to its human contracts ‚Äì mostly because they are a small, close-knit group of eight. They don‚Äôt treat it like equipment ‚Äì they seem to like it and think of it as more of someone enslaved instead of a construct ‚Äì which Murderbot finds both weirdly endearing and weird in an ‚ÄúOMG! Help! The stupid humans want to TALK to me about feelings and stuff and OMG leave me alone!‚Äù way. Therefore, Murderbot is much more interested in keeping this group alive than most. Luckily for Murderbot‚Äôs contracts cause the shit hits the fan and splatters rather quickly.

I really don‚Äôt want to discuss much more of the plot than the above as I don‚Äôt want to spoil any of it. Suffice to say that Murderbot is a great character and All Systems Red was a great novella. I certainly plan on reading any new additions to this series.

I've had this in my peripheral vision for quite some time from watching Mara's channel, but admittedly I wouldn't have considered putting it on my TBR (I read science fiction only occasionally, though I certainly enjoy it) if I hadn't been trying out the library connection on my new ebook reader*; this was one of the few titles available for immediate check-out that rang a bell in my memory, so I just downloaded it and went into it without much foreknowledge or expectations.
Boy, was I swept away! I think I binged it in just under 3h, spaced out over one morning.

Since I am obviously writing this review with the objective of convincing others to read it as well, let me get one of the biggest plus points over right away: This is the first part of a series of novellas, each of them only about 100 pages long (only the most recent one, Network Effect, is a full-length novel of 500 pages), so if you're hesitant to commit yourself to yet another ongoing series, don't worry. I have already preordered the sequels at the library and am planning on binging them over the next long weekend.
But back to this book: It's told from the perspective of a humanoid AI robot that somehow managed to hack itself and has become sentient, with the outcome that it's now even less interested in the security jobs it's being deployed on and binge-watches TV shows whenever its full attention isn't absolutely required. Its self-chosen name - Murderbot. (Side note, I was just about to type "himself" even though they are sexless and haven't chosen a pronoun; I somehow always thought of them as vaguely male-like, probably because of the narrator of the audiobook and because the character's snarky voice reminds me a lot of Peter Grant from Rivers of London who also much prefers to play video games and watch TV than learn Latin grammar for his magic lessons or play busboy to the various goddesses of Thames tributaries, not to mention his actual day job as a policeman.)
Anyways, Murderbot is part of a survey package people can purchase from companies to explore planets and exploit their resources; they are a piece of equipment, albeit an intelligent one, and are often treated horribly by their clients, for whom they consequently have very little sympathy. But when his current clients start getting attacked and sabotaged by an unknown enemy on the supposedly uninhabitated planet, Murderbot's relationship with them must necessarily become a bit more personal - which means, first and foremost, less time for TV shows.

Perhaps my favourite element was Murderbot's sarcastic, devil-may-care attitude and narratorial voice. They really and truly just want to be left alone in their storage unit and watch TV shows all day cycle long, but the clumsy misadventures of their human clients make that difficult - strangely relatable. The plot of the story was exciting and refreshingly unambitious - there's no galactic peace at stake, no black hole threatening to swallow a whole solar system, no evil fleet tyrannising the intergalactic federacy -, and though the ending provided a good starting point for several possible future adventures, I felt like it wasn't entirely within Murderbots scope as a character 
to suddenly develop a taste for an independent life on the run. But honestly, that's just a minor complaint, everything else was great!

All Systems Red is a science fiction novella about a cyborg and its gradual integration with a human exploration team on another world.

The genre tropes are familiar to sf readers: a non- or semi-human character, exploration of an alien world, good scientists grappling with bad people.

I found the story to be pleasant enough to hold my attention. The struggle with an opposing force was an interesting one, with some room for scheming and treachery. The narrator is entertainingly introverted and disinterested in work, and would rather spend time by itself watching "serials" (I'm guessing science fiction themed soap operas).

Otherwise, All Systems Red receded rapidly from my memory. Writing this review I found it hard to summon up key details, nice passages, or even major plot points.

So why is it so successful, and why is my response so meh?

For me... partly I was unmoved by having seen all of this before. Semi/nonhuman characters growing towards humanity? Check. Spy versus spy? Check. To be honest, I was expecting more mayhem and body horror than the text delivered, based on the term "Murderbot," the title, and the cover's glowering grimness.

For fans? Reviews emphasize the charm of the cyborg, based on a combination of flaws and combat skills. As one put it, "Murderbot may have guns in their forearms, but they also have strong feelings about their entertainment."

I think there's a cultural politics here. First, the Murderbot has no gender and no interest in sex, a point which is made quite clearly. That may appeal to people interested in nonbinary gender, asexuality, and related cultural streams. Second, the character is a serious pop culture fan, which, again, must appeal to a lot of sf readers. Third, Murderbot is very competent throughout, which classically appeals to science fiction audiences. Fourth, there are references to slavery, as Murderbot is not human, but owned property. Its ultimately humanization is a positive arc, and may resonate with progressives deeply invested in the history of American slavery and racism. So some readers may appreciate the novella's politics, while others enjoy the traditional power fantasy.

Similarly, some reviewers praise the novella's worldbuilding. I'm going to charitably assume said reviewers have little sf experience. So why is this appealing? Because it's a reflection of our own world in a way that honors anxieties without going full dystopia. There's omnipresent surveillance, an evil/incompetent corporation, and dehumanization, yet there's also pop culture and the possibility of personal advancement. If I were in a darker mood, I'd argue that All Systems Red offers a nice way of selling people on how to come to terms with cyberpunk dystopia without actually resisting or, well, doing anything.

Two more points.
I see that the story won a major young adult award. If this is really a YA title, then I've approached it all wrong.

One final thought: All Systems Red may be a good gateway text for non-sf readers. It is reasonably short and accessible. It proceeds as a good pace without depending on too many genre tropes.

date: I must say I‚Äôm pretty disappointed by this one. I actually had really high expectations for the series. It sounded like tons of fun, I mean it‚Äôs Murderbot‚Äôs Diaries, you can‚Äôt go wrong with that. And the series is so popular, this is the first time a copy became available at the library with the other 3 all out. So how did this purported robotic awesomeness go awry‚Ä¶well, pretty much from the start. But subtly. Because the book isn‚Äôt by any means terrible and the concept is perfectly intriguing, it‚Äôs difficult to narrow down exactly why I didn‚Äôt care for it. There‚Äôs just‚Ä¶there are different ways to write science fiction and this wasn‚Äôt the way I prefer. Too tech heavy, too action heavy, not enough character writing. Except for the murderbot himself, he‚Äôs there, narrating it all with a wry sarcastic manner that goes above and beyond what one might expect from a SecUnit, that‚Äôs security unit for the uninitiated. So yes, your main course AI is artificially intelligent‚Ä¶and funny, but the constant barrage of action in a sort of manic warp speed world building gets to be too much. Maybe it‚Äôs because the author had to cram so much into a novella format, maybe it‚Äôs just how she writes. The story is somehow both very simple and very cluttered at the same time. I‚Äôm not even sure my review is doing the book justice, because to just explain it‚Ä¶it sounds good. The things that didn‚Äôt work for me are difficult to put into words. Let‚Äôs just say I‚Äôve recently completed Themis trilogy and that‚Äôs how one does fun with robots. And this wasn‚Äôt it. But the thing is Murderbot is such a fun character, he‚Äôs got the Gen X sulk, he binges on tv series to learn about people, he often just wants to be left alone. To be honest, he can be a lot at times and he may not be as funny as all that, but he's the only with with any discernible personality around for miles, so you learn tom tolerate his ways. In fact, he‚Äôs positively brimming with personality for someone with what you‚Äôd think would be a pretty impersonal job. I‚Äôd probably seriously consider checking out his further adventures. I appreciate his quest to find himself, it‚Äôs the quintessential meaning of life search for someone who isn‚Äôt all man and isn‚Äôt all machine. Maybe his further adventures will be more to my liking. But you, dear reader, please be aware I‚Äôm probably in a minority here, this is a very popular very well received book, NYT bestseller, prestigious award winner and so on. You might very well like it. Or at least enjoy meeting its surprisingly charming protagonist. And it‚Äôs such a quick read too.

My only complaint about this book is that it is too damn short.

I suppose it says something that a few of my favorite books that I‚Äôve read this year‚ÄîMy Sister the Serial Killer and The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie come to mind‚Äîraised the same complaint. These are all writers of the ‚Äúleave ‚Äòem wanting more‚Äù school, I guess, and maybe what I enjoyed about these books‚Äîthe strong voice in the case of All Systems Red and My Sister..., the sardonic tone and fantastically nonlinear timeline of Miss Jean Brodie, could not have sustained in a longer work. But short books do frustrate me, if only because there are some kinds of stories that can benefit from a more relaxed pace and more opportunity to flesh out characters.

The half-organic, half-robotic construct that calls itself Murderbot is a charming narrator and protagonist; having hacked the governor module that would bind it to carry out the orders of the humans who hire it, it nevertheless performs a half-assed version of its job, doing just as little as it can get away with so its self-modification won‚Äôt be noticed. Profoundly socially awkward, all it really wants is to be left alone to watch TV serials. And so it is delightful, if inevitable, that this sweet-natured entity develops a connection with a particularly progressive and kind group of humans--especially their wise leader--who treat it with rather more respect and dignity than it is accustomed to from its employers.

It‚Äôs a delightful arc, and I would have loved to have seen it unfold with a little more deliberation and subtlety. For instance, more could have been done with the one member of Murderbot's human band who is suspicious of the construct's intentions. A longer book would also have allowed more space for world-building, which was rather rushed, painting the society in which Murderbot operates only in the broadest of strokes. And it would have allowed more layers of plot; the plot here is intriguing but rather quickly dispensed with (again, there‚Äôs no time for any but a quick disposition).

Still, All Systems Red is the book that it is‚Äîshort and very sweet. I loved every second of it, and maybe I can look to the rest of the series to do a little of the building and layering that is absent from this stripped-down first installment.

Ever hate your job and just want to watch Netflix? Turns out Murderbots feel the same way.

At least, that‚Äôs the general attitude of the protagonist in Martha Wells‚Äô novella All Systems Red: ‚ÄúI could have become a mass murderer after I hacked my governor module, but then I realized I could access the combined feed of entertainment channels carried on the company satellites. It had been well over 35,000 hours or so since then, with still not much murdering, but probably, I don‚Äôt know, a little under 35,000 hours of movies, serials, books, plays, and music consumed ‚Ä¶ As a heartless killing machine, I was a terrible failure.‚Äù

That failure is due in part to the slipshod corruption of Murderbot‚Äôs employer. The interstellar contractor has the technological know-how to transport clients to other worlds via wormholes and supply them with cyborg security units (aka SecUnits and Imitative Human Bot Units), but they do it all on the cheap; the equipment they provide is often sloppily built and error-ridden. This includes the security units. Our narrator was able to hack its governor in the first place because an earlier version malfunctioned.

The glitch comes in handy when Murderbot‚Äôs current clients, a small survey team, are stranded on a planet with hidden dangers. The map the contractor provided is missing key sections. Another survey team breaks off communication. People start dying. Fortunately, Murderbot doesn‚Äôt have to follow orders anymore; it can think for itself. And it‚Äôs learned a lot from all the shows it‚Äôs been binging.

The resolution to the mystery is a bit anti-climactic, hinting at grubby motivations without really exploring them. But I loved the subversive humor in All Systems Red, and the way Wells plays with the concept of identity and what it means to belong‚ÄîMurderbot thinks of itself as human-adjacent despite experiencing emotions like shyness, apathy, gratitude, and self-loathing (it gave itself the name Murderbot). This is a character-driven story that manages to make a partially inorganic construct with guns in its forearms both likable and relatable.

So if you are bored and interested in distracting yourself with some short, fun sci-fi, give All Systems Red a try. Murderbot would approve.

All Systems Red was truly a delight. A snarky robot with a TV addiction? Who can resist that!

All planetary missions must be supplied by the Company and they must rent a Company supplied SecUnit, an android security guard. The narrator of All Systems Red is one such SecUnit, but it has hacked into the governor module and is now secretly autonomous. It refers to itself as Murderbot, and it really doesn‚Äôt care about it‚Äôs job ‚Äî guarding a team of scientists on a remote planet where there shouldn‚Äôt be problems anyway. Murderbot much prefers to hack into a satellite and gain access to 35,000 hours of entertainment media. This works out perfectly fine for Murderbot until a neighboring mission goes dark and their own humans may be in danger.

The plot is not what‚Äôs important about All Systems Red. Instead, this science fiction novella focuses on the inner life of it‚Äôs protagonist and narrator, Murderbot. I know what you‚Äôre thinking: this is probably one of those robot stories where there‚Äôs a lot of angst and questioning about the nature of humanity. All Systems Red isn‚Äôt like that. There‚Äôs absolutely zero angst, and Murderbot finds humans awkward and slightly annoying. It says it likes fictional humans better than real humans, which is entirely relatable.

Murderbot‚Äôs voice was far and away the best thing about All Systems Red. It‚Äôs hilarious! I was seriously laughing out loud while reading this. Robots with feelings are the best sort of robots, even if in this case our robot narrator is anti-social and largely apathetic. Although, Murderbot may be a bit less apathetic than it seems. While it professes to be horrified by the humans clumsy attempts to befriend it, it does seem to care about them beneath it all. As well as being astonishingly funny, it‚Äôs also quite heart warming.

I loved All Systems Red so much. It will undoubtedly end up being one of the best science fiction stories I read all year. Thank goodness Martha Wells is writing a sequel! I desperately need more.

Being a human can be seriously awkward at times. Being a murderbot can be seriously awkward all the time.

A mix of inorganic and organic parts, lethal weapons literally built into its arms, what might happen if the murderbot hacks its governor module to gain autonomy? Going berserk, embark on a mass murdering rampage? Nope, this hacked murderbot has downloaded a limitless feed of entertainment‚Äîmore than 35,000 hours, in fact.

All Systems Red is a sci-fi novella that is not one to get bogged down in the small scientific details and the hard and fast rules of this futuristic world. There's the company, a vaguely mentioned entity that has funded a group of researchers to survey a dangerous planet. Aside from some fancy gadgets, the science is glossed over to focus instead on the SecUnit, the formal name for murderbots. Every group of humans receive one, but not necessarily a hacked one obsessed with a TV show.

This murderbot is charming to say the least, its sarcastic, uncomfortable, and pessimistic perspective spawning all sorts of delightful humor. A deadpan remark here or there at the expense of some humans provides us with a hearty laugh. Perhaps that seems superficial at best, but you begin developing this sort of warm, tickling sensation (gasp, is that sentimentality?!) while watching murderbot become accumstomed to learning the "human" aspect of her group.

The murderbot may be deficient in the ways that we initially define ourselves to be human. Our basic appearance, our connections to other humans, our endeavors. In a way, this novella gives us a chance to watch an introverted robot learn to navigate the social world, allow its face to be seen by others, and realize that its agency can save people and foster mutual respect or friendship with others. Replace robot with person, and we come to realize just how normally "human" murderbot is.

And even if I'm not the biggest fan of short stories, I'll never turn my nose up at a fun but honest look at humanity.

Murderbot has hacked its own governor module. Technically it doesn‚Äôt have to listen to anyone or follow any program commands. But it does have to keep up some semblance of functionality so the company doesn't find out it‚Äôs been hacked. When Murderbot is rented by a team of scientists, it will encounter humans that have never worked with a SecUnit before. And just when it thinks the contract is going to be a boring one, the unexpected happens. Suddenly Murderbot will find itself doing a lot more than watching the scientists dig up soil samples.

Murderbot‚Äôs personality is fantastic. Picture a robot who knows it has a job to do, but would rather sit and watch soap operas all day. Begrudgingly Murderbot follows commands from the scientists, but it ignores all system commands. And every chance it gets, Murderbot is dissing the corporation that owns it. Martha Wells does clever world-building through Murderbot‚Äôs sarcastic remarks. Painting the corporate ruled world that does everything as cheap as possible for the readers to see.

Martha Wells also brings a new perspective to artificial intelligence. Instead of hearing about the doubts and fears from humans, readers have a chance to see through Murderbot‚Äôs eyes. It‚Äôs not comfortable being around humans. It would rather stay in the cargo hold than socialize. Its entire purpose before hacking itself was to be a security robot. But with Doctor Mensha‚Äôs team, it will be forced to come out of its shell and may just find that some humans aren‚Äôt so bad.

Packed within less than two hundred pages is a story that will grab you from the first sentence. The evolution of Murderbot was fantastic. The sarcastic humor was undeniably hilarious. And it all came together to create a world I crave to see more of.

As I said to a friend, I think it‚Äôs difficult to cram the kind of world-building good SFF stories require into the limited space a novella offers. Not impossible, but difficult.

Fortunately, Wells has crafted such a compelling, charismatic, fun, likeable voice for her protagonist that any initial gripes (namely, being confused by the deluge of universe-specific, spacey sci-fi lingo, whose meanings could only be gleaned using context clues) I had were swept away in a perfect storm of humour, excitement, suspense, and, to my delight, the kind of sociopolitical and philosophical questions that I inevitably find myself wondering about when reading sci-fi, but which too often go ignored when the author decides that themes of AI sentience and ethics are overdone or, god forbid, boring. Sorry, but if your world has a slave race, you need to talk about that. Yes, even if the slave race is robots.

When I read sci-fi, I want to know how these new worlds handle these issues, not take them for granted, and Wells does one better than either ignoring said issues entirely or feeding into derivative tropes - instead, the ethics of autonomy and sentience are woven into the very fabric of her narrative, cleverly delivered to the reader via Murderbot‚Äôs deadpan yet endearing narration. In the end, even the spacey sci-fi lingo worked to All Systems Red‚Äôs advantage, because now so much of the foundational world-building has been laid down that I can‚Äôt imagine how the series could do anything but go up from here.

Yay, Murderbot!

date: This was the latest free download from science-fiction publisher Tor, in exchange for belonging to their mailing list; in fact, they're offering up all four of Martha Wells' "Murderbot" novellas this week for free download, in anticipation of her first full-length Murderbot novel coming later this summer. This first story in the series is a simple little shoot-em-up that can be read in its entirety in a single afternoon, and I didn't find anything particularly wrong with it, which is why it's getting at least a middle-of-the-road score from me. But that said, its central metaphor -- about how Murderbot's story arc is a stand-in for the troubles autistic IT consultants have when trying to get along in a corporate office that has temporarily brought them in -- is done really, really heavy-handedly, without even a hint of subtlety or finesse, and overly obvious metaphors are a big pet peeve of mine; and when you remove this clunky metaphor, there's literally nothing left to this short, one-note story, which means it doesn't deserve any higher than a middle-of-the-road score either. I'm going to read the second novella tomorrow as well, but if it's no better than this one, I think that's going to be the end of me following along with the adventures of our Netflix-binging, no-eye-contact android hero.

I started reading All Systems Red in the go-between the other major series i planned on reading. I had hopes of reading something fun and simple but i ended up fully engrossed in Murderbot and the compulsively addictive read that Martha Wells has produced. This is a short and exciting ride that just kept getting better.

All Systems Red is a novella that gets a lot done in a short amount of time. Wells conveys a lot of emotion, narrative and plot progression that is concise and tidy. She has created a brilliant character in Murderbot, an anxious but courageous SecUnit. The story is told from Murderbot's point of view which works well within the novella because we have a dialogue of human emotions but from our very own Terminator. Wells has created a story that already has the groundwork that doesn't necessarily need to be built on within the confines of this story.

This was a great story. I can see why Wells has received so many accolades and i'll gladly move on with the story. Murderbot is a humorous and enjoyable character with organic components, artificial parts and a real human emotion that is portrayed perfectly.

date: All Systems Red is the first of Martha Wells' Murderbot diaries. It is written in a first-person narrative voice. The protagonist Murderbot is a security robot employed in the protection of a group of space scientists. It has hacked its governor module and is a free agent. The author Martha Wells has depicted its interactions with humans and sense of care for them very well. It reminded me of Asimov's R Daneel Olivaw, but Murderbot has a sharper and wicked sense of humor. He has a somewhat questionable ambition in his life. He downloads serials to watch at leisure. He calls the 700 hours of downloaded materials as media, which chiefly includes thrillers and dramas. He is very good at learning from them and surprising his scientist colleagues with his judgment in crucial situations. There are three more diaries in the series, and I think they are overpriced compared to the length of the novellas.

I read this book because my friend Ted recommended them, and I saw that a bunch of other friends - Hannah, Maura, Seamus - had also read it. I'm glad to say it was another successful recommendation. The book was an enjoyable, funny, almost-cozy sci-fi story at a very digestible length. In fact, I would have said it needed to be longer, except there are already seven books in the series, so there is plenty more!

The star of the show is the titular Murderbot, who makes for an exciting and interesting protagonist. Its perspective as a SecUnit makes it distinct from typical sci-fi protagonists and Wells writes effectively from this not-human (but in many ways, very-nearly-human) point of view. Some of the best parts of the book occur when Murderbot is forced to think about and act on this very fine line between being around and similar to humans, without being one itself. And of course, it has so much personality and humor! Though I don't think the book sets out to be "cozy," the focus on Murderbot's introspection gave it a very cozy feel, interspersed with intense and dramatic violence.

I also very much liked the setting. Wells does a really good job of making it feel like a distant future, but still retaining echoes of human systems and shortcomings. Wells' commentary on capitalism, labor, and surveillance are interesting and sharp without distracting from the quick pace and rapid plot of the story. Character representation likewise is quite good without Wells making a point of how representative she's being.

The pacing is yet another strength, though at time it was a little too fast for my taste. The book starts off with a pretty killer action sequence, and very rarely does it slow down from there. Especially given the book's length (my audiobook version was around 3 hours), it feels like its hurtling. While this is great for maintaining a reading flow and the book's sense of forward motion, at times I felt confused on how the plot moved and had to rewind to understand where a name, goal, or group came from. It's a fairly minor nitpick, though. I'll read the next one on Kindle to see if the audio version was what tripped me up.

Overall, I really enjoyed this one and look forward to reading the next. I'd definitely recommend it to someone needing to break a reading slump or who likes sci-fi stories. Because of its brevity, I would also recommend it to someone who wasn't sure if they'd like sci-fi or not, like my spouse. I'd recommend this to Matt and Tom, Russ, my Dad, Abby, and my brother Luke. Thanks for the rec, Ted!

I might have a new favorite science-fiction protagonist. The part machine, part human hybride who thinks of itself as (a) Murderbot is genuinely fascinating because it freed itself from outside control to do essentially the same thing it was set up to do. The only (and obviously very crucial) difference is that it does so self-consciously in the literal sense of the word.

On the surface, Murderbot is a somewhat whimsical character. It is decisively detached from its mission and from the scientists it is commissioned to protect. It spends as little time on the actual job as possible, instead watching hours of soap opera in the quieter moments on site. Its almost uncompromising indifference and preoccupation with TV are funny, sure. But more importantly, it's all part of a wonderfully subtle buildup.

To describe the setup in slightly richer terms, we have agency, a deep interest in human emotions and relationships (what else would be presented on the shows?), yet not even the beginnings of hope that it itself could enter into any sort of real relationship with the people it is there to protect. To spice things up, there is also a background of guilt and possibly redemption.

It's amazing to think that all of this is packed into a story that is simply much fun to read. The fast-paced mystery plot is very on-point when it comes to discoveries and it's very visual in its execution. The tech prose feels adequate and adds to the metallic vibe of the rather uninhabitable research site. It's almost as if you have the inevitable TV adaptation already running on your mind (it's coming, right?).

There are surprising twists and some tension, particularly after the team finds out about Murderbot's tinkering with its governor unit, yet Wells has too much taste to go for big shocks or outbursts of feeling. Instead, the story is full of little observations that gradually come together as representing a more meaningful relationship between Murderbot and the (pure) humans.

There is the acknowledgement that interaction between them is to some extent awkward for both parties, and even more so after they saw it without its helmet on. In fact, it itself prefers to wear the armor for "protection" (another sense of being self-conscious). There is the strange moment when it rides in a passenger seat and what this might imply had the humans known about its status. (Was this what it was? In the passenger cabin? I'm not sure anymore.) It saves one of the scientists and is later in turn saved by her. Then there is the debate on whether it can be trusted. Can its action so far be taken as evidence for its well-meaning attitude? At least it appears to demonstrate that it's capable of taking an attitude and that it ought to be treated as a person.

The events have this enticing philosophical dimension throughout. For one thing, there is something striking about the idea of a (part) robot that acts as if it was a robot. Then there is the intricate difference between being contractually obliged and being programmatically determined to do something, especially in the case where no free consent was given to take up the contract. And of course there is the existential demand of setting your own goals to give meaning to your actions, especially prevailing towards the end of the story.

Murderbot is now free to explore the nearby universe on its own. I'm very excited to see where its story goes from here and how it growth further as a person.

Rating: 4/5

I thought I had this series on my TBR for years but apparently this first novella was only published in 2017 lol. Well okay I guess that's still 3 years ago! But still I thought it was longer. Anyway! I finally read the first novella today! And it was funny and enjoyable and relatable and I'm really glad I read it.

Let's just start off with the first paragraph of the novella so you can get an idea of the tone.

"I could have become a mass murderer after I hacked my governor module, but then I realized I could access the combined feed of entertainment channels carried on the company satellites. It had been well over 35,000 hours or so since then, with still not much murdering, but probably, I don't know, a little under 35,00 hours of movies, serials, books, plays, and music consumed. As a heartless killing machine, I was a terrible failure."

A bot designed to kill who hacks its programming and spends its time...watching tv. Yep, sounds on brand for a lot of us haha. Murderbot, as it calls itself, is incredibly socially awkward - and because of that, it is super easy to relate to. Reading about its interactions with the team of humans it has been tasked with protecting is hilarious and heartwarming. Watching Murderbot come to care for them as people and not as clients is great. And on the flip side, seeing the clients warm up to Murderbot and come to accept it as one of them is wonderful too.

This is a novella that I think is actually the perfect length. I recently read the Wayward Children series, and from those I want MORE. In this case, I found the actual plot to be a bit weak and not very compelling. The plot is vague until the very end, which I found to be a bit unsatisfying. However, I think that made the length perfect - this way the plot didn't drag on too long and become tedious and boring.

I'm glad there are more novellas to read! I honestly just like reading about Muderbot as a character, I think it is interesting and hilarious. So here are some final quotes I'll leave you with!

"...I liked the imaginary people on the entertainment feed way more than I liked real ones, but you can't have one without the other."
"They had talked it all over and all agreed not to "push me any further than I wanted to go" and they were all so nice and it was just excruciating. I was never taking off the helmet again."
"Yes, talk to Muderbot about its feelings. The idea was so painful I dropped to 97% efficiency. I'd rather climb back into Hostile One's mouth."

Nowhere Book Bingo 2025: First in a series

Nowhere Book Bingo 25: First in a series

It's been five years since I first read The Murderbot Diaries
Even now, having read the whole series, I still find a lot of the supporting characters who are introduced in this story a bit confusing, and they mostly blend together for me. Doctor Mensah is an obvious exception since Murderbot respects her so much.

The structure of the novella is also a bit wonky. It starts relatively slow, and then there's a series of dramatic events before the story ends very abruptly, possibly too quickly.

I also feel like I should address the Apple TV adaptation of this novella, which manages to capture the tone and feel of the story while making some pretty massive changes. Quite a few of the supporting characters have been cut (the fact that it works as well as it does suggests that Wells probably didn't need the Pres Aux team to be as big as it is in the novella - no wonder I keep getting the characters confused). Skarsg√•rd plays an excellent Murderbot, even though he's not Murderbot as I imagine it (the Murderbot in my head is female presenting, more like Gwendoline Christie as Brienne of Tarth rather than tall, handsome and Scandinavian), and I can't help but think that our favourite SecUnit's extreme social awkwardness is portrayed so well since Skarsg√•rd is so familiar with Scandinavians and our weird introverted way of being. No one in Scandinavia likes being talked to by strangers or having FEELINGS shared all over them.

One of my favourite things about the adaptation is the choice to have scenes from Murderbot's favourite media shown to the viewers. If I wasn't already pretty sure I'd be hooked on Sanctuary Moon, seeing the brief snippets of it on screen confirms it. There is still an episode left to go, but so far, I think the show may be dealing with the confusing end section of the story better than in the novella. Time will tell.

June 2018: 4.5 stars

Recently, I read Binti by Nnedi Okorafor, which won the 2016 Nebula award for best novella. I was rather underwhelmed by that story. All Systems Red just won the Nebula for best novella for 2018, and I thought that was a much more deserving winner - and a much more engaging and well-written story besides.

I think a lot of introverted and nerdy readers on the internet can identify with Murderbot, who has hacked its own governor module and spends all of its downtime (and any other spare moments it can get away with it) consuming the countless hours of entertainment media it has sneakily downloaded. As it points out in the very first lines of the novella, it could have become a mass murdering killing machine after hacking its governor module, but with all that media to consume, who has the time? Murderbot finds social interaction deeply awkward and absolutely hates small talk and especially talking about feelings of any kind, which makes the fact that several of the scientists keep trying to engage it in conversation and treating it as an important member of the crew, not just a mindless droid (it's not mindless, of course, but it also would rather be left alone). Muderbot loves its armour and hates having to be without it, which becomes a bit of an issue as the story goes on - its duty is to protect the scientists and unexpectedly, what was supposed to be a pretty routine research mission turns out to be really rather dangerous.

The first instalment of The Murderbot Diaries is an excellent example of why I keep trying science fiction, a genre that is more often than not miss than hit for me. It's not that I hate all sci-fi stories, it's just that the ones that I really like and that manage to really engage me emotionally are few and far between. Since Murderbot clearly is some sort of spiritual cousin to Marvin the Paranoid Android (I first read The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy in my early teens) and also has many of the same anxious reactions to socialising as I frequently do, not to mention wants nothing but to be left alone and consume mindless entertainment, I (like so many other readers) couldn't help but love it.

The second novella in this series is out now, but I'm not allowing myself to read it until I'm fully and completely caught up on my backlog. Happily, while it's taking a while, I am slowly but surely churning out reviews and should be able to read about Murderbot's next adventure soon.

Judging a book by its cover: This cover shows Murderbot, in its armour that it finds so comforting, front and centre. The background is suitably ominous, considering the contents of the story. I like that the art is done in such a way that this almost looks like black and white, except it's not.

I had heard about The Muderbot Diaries from people who had great things to say about its characters, but I had very little idea about the plot. I vaguely understood that there is a surly robotic humanoid who is regularly baffled at humans but also (without admitting it) desires human connection. And maybe something with found family?

Honestly, I don't get why people like it so much. Is it the found family trope? I can't stand found family if it doesn't feel earned, and I think a 150-page cap dooms the story to fail in that endeavor, if that's what the author was going for. I don't think that was the intent, though. 
The human crew treat buying out Muderbot's contract like taking a stray animal off the street and trying to adopt it as a pet. Maybe the sequels will develop their relationship into something more genuine and equal?

I also just haven't read something in first person in a while, and it was a bit jarring to get into at first. There's nothing wrong with first person, but in my mind, it is typically associated with more YA styles, and the fact that Muderbot talks like a depressed college student who just wants to rot on the couch watching TV shows and avoid all responsibility unfortunately reinforced that association with juvenility.

On the bright side, this was super short, as it is a novella, so I don't feel annoyed at the time spent on it. I still want to read the sequels because I feel like I'm missing something. What am I supposed to like?

All Systems Red is the first story in Martha Wells‚Äô Hugo, Nebula, and Locus award-winning Murderbot Diaries series.
