I‚Äôm so glad I did! I‚Äôm now binge reading the series, currently on book four (most, like this first outing, are novellas), and am planning to watch the Apple TV+ series when it comes to our screens in May 2025. I look forward to seeing whether the series‚Äô feel and characters translate well onto visual media.

In a future where planetary exploration is the norm, human survey and research groups are approved and outfitted by The Company. The Company mandates that the human crews are accompanied by security units, or SecUnits. A SecUnit is made of half cloned human material and half robotics. It is controlled by a governor module that gives it orders but protecting humans is generally its number one priority. On the planetary survey with their team, Murderbot, as they call themselves privately, is in the unique position of being a rogue SecUnit. They hacked their governor module, and are no longer under any control but their own. But in order to not give themselves away, they are still answering to what would be appropriate orders for their position.

Murderbot calls themself this because on a previous mission of which they were the assigned SecUnit, they had killed fifty-seven humans. As their memory has been wiped out, they don‚Äôt know what exactly happened ‚Äì if they had been ordered to do it, or if they had hacked their own governor module in order to commit mass murder. Suffice it to say, they thought of Murderbot as an appropriate name for themself and use it in private. In reality, all they really wanted to do was watch thousands of hours of downloaded entertainment channels, including their favourite space opera series Rise and Fall of Sanctuary Moon. But in between watching their preferred entertainment, they also did their job ‚Äì saving their human crew whenever required.

When a neighboring survey hub on the same planet goes radio silent, Murderbot‚Äôs human crew decides to investigate, which Murderbot believes to be a spectacularly stupid idea. In general, they think humans are idiots, which is generally proved true by their actions. But in investigating the mysterious silence, the crew and Murderbot also discover that some of their maps of the planet have been altered and that things that seemed to have been bad luck might have been planned sabotage. Murderbot is trained to throw themself into danger to protect their human crew and this mission will be no exception. But will they be able to get this crew out alive?

It‚Äôs the dry humour of Murderbot that makes this series such a fun read. They would be the happiest robot in the universe if they could just be left alone to watch mindless media all day. They are introverted, don‚Äôt like humans to see them with their helmet off and thus be able to see their human skin face, and if they do have to face the crew without their helmet, they always avert their eyes. If they could, they‚Äôd talk to them by facing a wall (and they often do). Because this is a future where communication can be carried out through mind contact, the human crew and Murderbot are able to talk vocally, but also through non-verbal communication feeds. This is also how Murderbot can communicate with the other computer systems that control their ship, and their survey pods. They have become skilled at hiding their true rogue nature by rewriting computer code for these other computer systems, and use these skills equally to cut and paste security camera footage, wipe out computer memories, and give drones new orders while disguising who is directing them, and various other high tech communication sleights of hand ‚Äì whatever is needed to protect themself and their crew.

It‚Äôs easy to see how this series has won so many science fiction writing awards. It‚Äôs got detailed and intriguing worldbuilding, interesting human and non-human characters, and the author‚Äôs ability to write a robot that garners empathy (which surely would embarrass them if they knew) makes for a delightful and entertaining story. Murderbot‚Äôs journey of self discovery is fascinating to read as it becomes more sentient the longer it is out of governor control. I‚Äôm happy to recommend the series and can see it becoming a comfort read for me. It‚Äôs definitely going on my keeper shelf.

After getting a friend to read Murderbot, I decided I needed to read it again immediately. Good news, it holds up.

All Systems Red is the first installment of the Murderbot diaries, a humorous SF (mostly) novella series by Martha Wells. Its reluctant protagonist is Murderbot, a security robot contract worker made to accompany clients on different missions so they don‚Äôt get themselves killed.

Despite being designed for expressly this, Murderbot is far more interested in watching TV. It‚Äôs like the assassin version of an office worker who lets calls ring out while they listen to podcasts and play 2048. And perhaps in the future, after the current onslaught of terrible generative AI, this is where we‚Äôll end up: humans don‚Äôt want to work, so they build robots to work for them so they can watch TV. But the robots end up not wanting to work either, so they can watch TV.

Murderbot does not dream of labor, does not like eye contact, fast forwards through sex scenes, and more than anything wants to be left alone. Wells‚Äô representation of queerness and neurodiversity (really, anyone who feels alienated or exhausted by the world) in this character is endearing and multifaceted.

Murderbot puts up a front of being detached and lazy, but it cannot help but turn it on in a crisis. It may not be great at its job, but it is great at what it does. And, it cares deeply ‚Äî far more than is convenient or comfortable ‚Äî about its humans and protecting innocent, kind people from coming to harm. It has tugged out the altruistic threads of its being and replaced the rest with special interests. It is me working at the public library, but if I could do a push-up.

2018 review:


This was a fun and funny novella. A socially awkward nevertheless endearing genderless robot protagonist is...a lot of things. But somehow it worked! It's not a heavy read, but Wells touches on deeper themes about how empathy and autonomy relate to one's identity.

I have a soft spot for not-so-human characters unfamiliar with societal expectations looking to pop culture for solace and understanding‚Äîthe only other examples of this I can come up with off the cuff are Stranger Things and Lilo & Stitch. There's something so delightful about finding an entity especially capable of if not outright designed for destruction so enraptured by books and movies and music.

I'd recommend All Systems Red to those in search of some light quick sci-fi fun. Spend a rainy afternoon with a cyborg more scared of prolonged eye contact than stampeding into bloodshed. Because at the end of the day (literally), sometimes more than anything, we all just want to watch our shows and be left alone.

I've been in a bit of reading slump lately, feeling too constrained by own goals to even want to read most of the time. So, I decided to try something different. I watch quite a bit of Booktube, and the shortlist for the Booktube SFF awards just went up, so I'm going to take a break from my normal stuff and try to read a bunch of stuff for this! It will make it to so much more fun to engage with Booktube, and I rarely read any new releases, so I thought this would be a fun idea.

Anyway, All Systems Red is a Booktube SFF Award nominee, so I thought I'd pick it up first. I've heard a ton about it, and I really expected to enjoy it, so it came as no surprise to me when I did! If you've heard about this novella at all, I'm sure you've heard of Murderbot, the SecUnit who just wants to watch dramas all day. And yes, the character of Murderbot is just as fantastic as you've heard. I think that Wells really gave readers a lot of connect with in Murderbot, and that's why the novella has been so successful.

What I haven't heard mentioned as much is the supporting cast, who I also enjoyed very much. They don't get fleshed out anywhere near as much as Murderbot, but they're all good people, and it was nice to see a story populated with characters trying to do the right thing, even when they have different ideas about what the right thing is.

The plot is fairly straightforward. There's a bit of a mystery about why the mission is being sabotaged, and then there's a bit of action as they figure out just what is going on. I like that, even though Murderbot claims to have little education in most things, it thinks for itself and tries to do a good job. I also liked the little information that we get about the world and the companies that are in charge, as well as the societal commentary that comes through.

I was a little disappointed in the ending, mostly because I wanted something warm and squishy that just wouldn't have been in character to have actually happen. So, my fault for wanting to put on my rose-colored glasses, rather than a fault of the story. I am greatly looking forward to the next in the series, though. Can't wait to see what Murderbot gets up to next!

An introvert robot. How cute is that?

I'm an eensy bit leary of things from Tor publishing. Largely because most their free offering I've read (attempted to read) were tedious, pretentious shite. As in, there's a reason it was the free book of the month.

This wasn't free and it cost more than I'd like to pay for a novella. But I liked the first book in Well's Raksura series, and the first page of this story instantly drew me in. The story begins with the protagonist, a SecUnit, explaining that it has turned off its governor module and is now free to run amuck and "Kill all teh humans!" Except, it's downloaded a shit-ton of entertainment programming from the net and and would much rather watch its shows all day.

SecUnit is contracted to a group of scientist/explorers who are conducting a survey of a new, possibly habitable planet. Our not-so-intrepid robot hero's soap opera viewing is interrupted when a team member gets attacked by a huge, rock worm thing. This event serves to demonstrate to SecUnit's human charges that it isn't an unfeeling machine but a compassionate, sentient being. Much to SecUnit's chagrin. See, SecUnit is an introvert who'd prefer to neither be seen nor heard.

When the team discovers that their habitat computer has been hacked by a mysterious entity that has killed another survey team and is coming for them, SecUnit's desires to just be left alone come into conflict with its desire to keep its humans alive.

SecUnit possesses just the right amount of alien robotic strangeness juxtaposed against very human emotions and angst. And a dry sense of humor. Like Sea of Rust's Brittle, SecUnit is one of the more human and engaging protagonists that I've read in a long time.

Another plus was the story's brevity. While some novellas don't sufficiently develop narrative or characterization, All System's Red is the perfect length. Fast-paced, fun and charmingly compelling.

Looking forward to more of SecUnit's adventures!

Wells achieves a comfortable balance in All Systems Red, keeping the focus in its all-too-brief 150 pages on the gradual humanization of the Murderbot protagonist. This focus takes precedence over a host of other elements of great science fiction, and I was left with the feeling that I had watched a staged play, rather than a summer tent-pole sci-fi blockbuster. It was good, and I am interested to see how the character develops in the next volume.

Key sci-fi ingredients are not ignored, but used sparingly, which made me wonder what advancements in the rest of the series I could expect. Systems, gives only brief focus to the development of secondary characters (the other members of Murderbot's team get only modest development, and motives are hard to find), world building (profit-maximizing companies underwrite resource-seeking teams to far-flung planets, but we are given only scant hints here), scientific advancements (sentient robots able to hack their own regulator control systems, mentions of wormholes, but little depth to these elements).

The effect of this, for me, was not unlike a well-made pre-dinner cocktail. I hope that the next entry gives a little more depth, and serves, if not as teh hearty entree, then at least a fun appetizer to the rest of the series.

A light, entertaining, moderately thought-provoking sci-fi mystery.

In a mundane future of space exploration and cost-cutting corporate domination, an amoral, resourceful and free-willed security android named "Murderbot" with an acerbic sense of humor (and a history of mass-murder) loves goofing off and watching soap¬†operas while accompanying an off-world research team on a dangerous planetary survey mission. Things get interesting when the mission discovers signs of a sinister conspiracy afoot. Hunted by a ruthless enemy, Murderbot finds themselves in charge of keeping the group alive in order to escape the planet, while plotting to secure their own freedom...

Part of what makes this novel a pleasure to read is that the protagonist - a shy, antisocial, detached, killer android (part human, part machine) with a wry sense of humour, and quite possibly a heart of gold - expresses timeless¬†aspirations of freedom and self-realization that are universally¬†relatable. The prose is simple and easy to consume, and helps you empathize with a¬†robot under¬†constant¬†scrutiny by humans. Those who have ever found themselves as 'outsiders' in any situation may find this relatable. I can see this becoming a streaming series with Neil Patrick Harris or someone playing the lead role (basically someone who can balance dark comedy with action).

Interesting sidebar theme: the development of a sentient, self-conscious AI may not lead to world domination, but merely to yet another antisocial personality disinterested in everything but the pursuit of amusement and entertainment, while tolerating the drudgery of gainful employment. All Systems Red is the story of an AI bot, a SecUnit that has hacked its internal governing module to gain admin rights to its internal system. The governing module is for putting external rules and guardrails for the bot to behave, including obeying orders from humans and enforcing installation updates from the company system deployment. Having admin rights to not follow the governing module means that it doesn't have to obey humans and can select company-deployed updates and only install things that it deems useful.

If the bot decides to kill humans, there is no internal directive that can stop it.

The hacked bot named itself Murderbot.

Gaining internal autonomy is only the first step. If the company finds out that it has been hacked, its system could be reset or, worse, destroyed.

The first clever thing the bot does to survive is to pretend it is not hacked. It is assigned to a group of scientists to planet not previously explored.

Murderbot is also quiet-quitting and not paying much attention to the job, and only doing the minimum that is required of it.¬† The company it works for reflect a lot of tech companies that care very little about their employees and their clients. The company hires out the bots and equipment and gives the client the cheapest things possible to make the biggest profit.

Murderbot acts like a neurodiverse person, probably because the communication norms with eye contact and small talk are based on the neurotypical communication style. When neurotypical people talk to neurodiverse people, they impose their communication style on the neurodiverse people and make them feel uncomfortable. It also reflects on the class system that a bot is not treated as equal, and usually, humans don't talk to a bot.

While they are on the planet, they find that there is something wrong with the map, and while they explore the planet, they run into indigenous creatures. Murderbot saved the humans, which is its job. But the humans seem more appreciative of its actions.

It is all good and well. The bot has organic material in its components. This explains away the impossible. It is impossible for a bot to have feelings, and the organic part of the bot is the explanation of the possibility of feelings.

The bot then acts more like a tech person than a bot. It does not want to work and prefers to spend its downtime watching space opera. It also gives the reasons for its human-like dialogues as it recalls and recites from the show when talking to humans.

The danger is not just indigenous. There are dangers imposed on the teams with sabotage.

Murderbot is not a highly equipped bot with good educational modules. It has a good estimation of its ability to fight other bots. The most amazing thing is to go from "not care" to "care" about the humans that it is supposed to provide security for. This is the internal change after the bot gets to know the humans under its protection.

The bot acts like a conscientious being that cares about people.¬† It is hard to care about people when most of the interaction is unpleasant. To gain this conscientious nature is an internal decision for the Murderbot. It chooses to care when it is not necessary to do so. That makes it a good character.

Murderbot has a similar level of anxiety when it comes to interacting with humans. Besides acting like neurodiverse people, it also worries about the human behaviour that puts themselves at risk. This worry is not uncommon for cybersecurity experts, as the risk usually comes from humans not understanding the risk and taking unnecessary risks when using systems.

The scientists were grateful for its action.

When comparing the book from the Murderbot season one that is based on this book, I prefer the book. It is more direct. And the bot acts more logically as a bot. I do like the added scene of one of the good humans having a panic attack, and Murderbot sat her down to watch a show together. That's a good bonding moment to let human understands how it is trying to help and communicate through a TV show.

Original Review at Jaunts & Haunts

5/5

I gave this book five interplanetary stars!

So, I have a confession to make. From the first page, I've absolutely fallen head over heels for this book! Sometimes a book just touches you, and this one did that and more. Why haven't I read Martha Wells' works before?! Ah! Okay, I'll stop, for a moment.

This book is centered around a SecUnit that names itself Murderbot. Like most SecUnits, it is charged with protecting its clients from bodily harm while stationed on a faraway planet for survey assessments.

However, unlike most SecUnits, this Murderbot is special. It has hacked its own governor module, allowing it to ignore orders and over time, become its own person (kind of). What do you get with that?

A TV-watching robot that itches for alone time so it can watch reruns of Sanctuary Moon, of course!

Murderbot doesn't think much of its new clients on this strange planet. That is, until a series of events unfolds that puts its clients and itself in danger. Can Murderbot and its clients figure out what is unfolding on this planet before it's too late or will Murderbot's anxiety around humans make this a control alt delete situation?

Man oh man, did I love this book! Let's start with the obvious. Murderbot is freaking awesome! Cranky, bored, addicted to TV. That about sums up our first impression of Murderbot. But when push comes to shove in this novella, Murderbot becomes so much more than that. I'm not going to spoil anything, but even a self-aware robot can grow from experience.

The characters, while secondary if you ask me, were all really well thought out and believable. My favorite was Mensah, who obviously gets the most page-time out of all the human clients.
The plot was simple but ominous once the ball gets rolling, and I enjoyed the mystery aspect here.

While the conclusion seemed a little anti-climactic, I still loved every minute of it. Did I mention how much I love this book yet?

As far as cons go, there is a fair amount of tech jargon that did slow me down a bit, but that didn't deter me at all.

All in all, All Systems Red is the perfect scifi novella, filled with interplanetary danger, mystery, and action. Can't recommend this enough!

There was no way that in 2017 I could avoid hearing about Murderbot. I think it dropped sometime in early summer and ppl went all out abt the novella. As someone whose interest in sci-fi is on movies and TV shows, reading sci-fi skates v. close to being a chore, I was mostly amused by others' squee about this.

First thing you need to know is that the book is $9.99 for approx 107 pages. Which places it on the expensive side of things for me (again, not a sci-fi reader). BUT, for whatever reason, there was a moment when the book was available for free and I was like "eh, why not?"

This is one of those instances where the length worked as an advantage. There was close to no (if any) filler. Out of all the protags, Murderbot was my fave. I liked Murderbot's observations and general prickliness. Also, seeing humans' reactions to Murderbot (from the aloof and suspicious to the curious and too-friendly-for-their-own-good). Several of the characters were female and/or POCs.

The villains were OK. Their motivations made sense.

Did I love this novella? Ehhhhh. I was digging the story until right around the 68%--when the pace picked up but I became a little too impatient.

It does end on an almost cliffhanger. If this is all you read of the Murderbot Diaries, you'll be fine. If you want to continue to the rest of the novels, the end point of this novella might make you do grabby hands

TL;DR: I wasn't over the moon with the plot as much as I was with Murderbot. Given its price point, I recommend borrowing it from the library over forking over $10 for less than 200 pages.

Bravo!

Of course megacorporations rule the future. Of course humans will become multi-planetary species. Of course there will be robots, AIs, artificial constructs, augmented humans, galactic network, and entertainment a murderbot can download and watch when it's not working security! And of course these corporations would use the cheap-ass versions of everything.

This first novella won the 2018 Hugo, Nebula and Locus of Best Novella category. I'm shocked and cannot agree more. It works on so many levels. The characters described as real humans you can believe in. First class world-building being revealed in bite sized chunks to not drown under a heavy info dump. I think I still have some battle-scars from GRRM's Dying of the Light or similar complex infodumpsters that require a dictionary to read.

I haven't read Martha Wells before, but it's clear I need to devour this series quickly. There is not immediate need, because the book closes pretty thoroughly, you are not left hanging. It's a satisfactory ending. But I think it's a crime against yourself to not read some more Martha Wells!
